and to hear oral arguments October 5, 1981; adjourned
October 4, 1982......

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY OCTOBER 5, 1981
1
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"I have the honor to announce on behalf of the Court that the October
1981 Term of the Supreme Court of the United States is now con-
vened."
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
Mr. Deputy Solicitor General Lawrence G. Wallace presented the
Honorable Rex E. Lee, Solicitor General of the United States.
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Solicitor General, the Court welcomes you to the performance of
the important office that you have assumed, to represent the govern-
ment of the United States before this Court. Your commission will be
duly recorded by the Clerk."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-1795. In the Matter of 18.86 Acres of Real Property, now
Known as Lot 35, Block 57, Section 19, Located in Pittsgrove Town-
ship, Salem County, etc., Appellant. Appeal from the Superior Court of
New Jersey, Appellate Division. The appeal is dismissed for want of ju-
risdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Justice O'Connor took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 80-1867. Edward John Williams, Appellant v. Ohio. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Paulding County. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Justice
O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 80-2181. Lloyd Vickroy, Appellant v. United States Department
of the Navy, Long Beach Naval Shipyard. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Justice
O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

2
MONDAY OCTOBER 5, 1981
No. 80–6668. Lyle H. Prenzler, Appellant v. Conrad J. Kleinman, et
al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the pa-
pers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
No. 80–6696. Millicent Linden, Appellant v. David Fox, et al. Appeal
from the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York, First Judi-
cial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 80-6834. Lyle H. Prenzler, Appellant v. R. Keith Pike, et al. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of this case.
No. 81-13. Robert L. Menegus, Appellant v. E. I. du Pont de Ne-
mours & Co. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 81-29. Milton F. Kirsner, Appellant v. Maryland; and Earl Re-
alty, Inc., Appellant v. Maryland. Appeal from the Criminal Court of
Baltimore. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this case.
No. 81–158. Michael Papadopoulos, Appellant v. Oregon State Board
of Higher Education. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Oregon. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of this case.
No. 81–5143. Millicent Linden, Appellant v. Dial Press, et al. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of this case.

MONDAY OCTOBER 5, 1981
3
co
No. 80-1837. Faith Baptist Church of Louisville, Nebraska, et al.,
Appellants v. Paul L. Douglas, Attorney General of Nebraska, et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Nebraska. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question. Justice O'Connor took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 80-1955. Carter County Fiscal Court, et al., Appellants v. Carter
County Public Library District, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Kentucky. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision
of this case.
No. 80-1956. Bertie Otis Whidden, Jr., Appellant v. New York. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question. Justice O'Connor took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 80-2045. Donald Lynn Billman, Appellant v. Columbus Bar
Association. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Ohio. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice O'Connor took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 80-2047. Leonard Kulick, Sidney Kulick, Howard Shirvan and
Stanley Shirvan, Appellants v. Department of Revenue, State of Ore-
gon. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Oregon. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice O'Connor took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 80-2051. Fidelity Union Trust Company, etc., et al., Appellants
v. New Jersey Highway Authority, etc., et al. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of New Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this case.
No. 80-2131. Southern Pacific Transportation Company, Appellant v.
Public Utilities Commission of California, et al. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of California. The appeal is dismissed for want of sub-
stantial federal question. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this case.
No. 80-2139. John R. Wise, Appellant v. Georgia State Board for the
Examination, Qualification and Registration of Architects, et al. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question. Justice O'Connor took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 80-2164. Russel G. Schlenz, et al., Appellants v. John W. Castle,

4
MONDAY OCTOBER 5, 1981
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice O'Connor took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 80-2202. Bally Manufacturing Corporation, Appellant v. New
Jersey Casino Control Commission. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
New Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision
of this case.
No. 80-2207. Milton J. Smith, etc., Appellant v. Commissioner of
Revenue. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Jus-
tice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 80-6662. Harold Michael Newton and Roger Lynn Stricker, Ap-
pellants v. Arkansas. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Arkansas. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice
O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 80-6878. Michael Gerald Vandenberg, Appellant v. Oregon, et al.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Oregon. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question. Justice O'Connor took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 80-6948. Jonathan Bruce Reed, Appellant v. Texas. Appeal from
the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question. Justice O'Connor took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 81-10. Robert Lorraine Stallard, Appellant v. Carolyn Franklin
Stallard. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice O'Connor took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 81-50. Prudence J. Camardo, et al., Appellants v. City of Roch-
ester, N. Y., et al. Appeal from the Appellate Division, Supreme Court
of New York, Fourth Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question. Justice O'Connor took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 81-84. Ben Bundo, Jr. and Ben Bundo, Sr., Appellants v. Michi-
gan Liquor Control Commission. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
Michigan. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision
of this case.

MONDAY OCTOBER 5, 1981
5
No. 81–131. Quinn-Moore, et al., Appellants v. Beverly J. Lambert,
etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Arkansas. The appeal is

took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

istration and Education of the State of Illinois and Joan G. Anderson,
etc. Appeal from the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District. The ap-

O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 81-5101. David Michael Barnett, Appellant v. Texas. Appeal
from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question. Justice O'Connor took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 80-1841. Joshua C. Agsalud, etc., et al., Appellants v. Standard
Oil Company of California. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. The judgment is affirmed.
No. 80-1960. David Willson, Appellant v. State Personnel Board, etc.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Third Appellate Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 80-6743. Eddie Samuel Ivory, et al., Appellants v. Louie L.
Wainwright, Secretary, Department of Corrections, et al. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 80–1977. Linda F. Mason, Appellant v. Robert B. Abrams, At-
torney General of New York. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New
York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion. Justice Brennan and Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdic-
tion and set the case for oral argument.
No. 80-1992. Roger Barth, Appellant v. Morgan M. Finley, Circuit
Clerk. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice Brennan and
Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for
oral argument.
No. 80-6655. Margaret Batterham Waters, Appellant v. Fred Hen-
derson, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Eastern
Section. The motion of Frank S. Bloch, et al. for leave to file a brief as
amici curiae is denied. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

6
MONDAY OCTOBER 5, 1981
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-1872. Gary Allen, Petitioner v. James B. Ellisor, etc. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit with directions to consider whether the
case has become moot by reason of the enactment of Act R 655, effec-
tive March 20, 1981, whereby § 7-5-120(5)(b) of the South Carolina
Code of Laws, 1976, was amended. See Crowell v. Mader, 444 U.S. 505
(1980).
No. 80-2159. Robert C. Lehman, Petitioner v. E. B. Weiss. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Parratt v. Taylor, 451 U.S. (1981).
No. 80-2172. Seekonk Water District, Petitioner v. Heritage Homes
of Attleboro, Inc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari
is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of City of Newport v. Fact Concerts, Inc., 453 U.S.
-(1981).
No. 81-82. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v.
Horacio Ramos Miranda. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Schweiker v. Hanson, 450 U.S. (1980).
No. 81-211. Michigan, Petitioner v. Maurice Hurd. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the Court of Appeals of Michigan to consider
whether its judgment is based upon federal or state constitutional
grounds, or both. See California v. Krivda, 409 U.S. 33 (1972).

No. 80-2100. Quentin Rogers, et al., Appellants v. Herman Lodge, et
al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Cir-
cuit. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.

nue Department of the State of New Mexico. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of New Mexico. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted. The
case is set for oral argument in tandem with No. 80-2015, ASARCO,
Inc. v. Idaho State Tax Commission.
No. 80-2015. ASARCO Incorporated, etc., Appellant v. Idaho State
Tax Commission. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Idaho. In this case
probable jurisdiction is noted. The case is set for oral argument in tan-
dem with No. 80-1745, F. W. Woolworth Co. v. Taxation and Revenue
Department of New Mexico.
No. 80-2165. James M. Murphy, District Judge, Fourth Judicial Dis-
trict of the State of Nebraska, Douglas County, Appellant v. Eugene L.
Hunt. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted. Justice Blackmun
would postpone further consideration of the question of jurisdiction to
the hearing of the case on the merits.
No. 80–1832. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Appellant v.
Jagdish Rai Chadha, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit;
No. 80-2170. United States House of Representatives, Petitioner v.
Immigration and Naturalization Service, et al.; and
No. 80-2171. United States Senate, Petitioner v. Immigration and
Naturalization Service, et al. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Further consid-
eration of the question of jurisdiction is postponed to the hearing of the
case on the merits in No. 80-1832. The petitions for writs of certiorari in
Nos. 80-2170 and 80-2171 are granted. The cases are consolidated and a
total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.

451 U.S. (1981).

No. 80-2059. John D. Randall, Petitioner v. W. W. Reynoldson, et
al.; and
No. 80-2060. In the matter of John D. Randall, Petitioner. Petitions
for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit denied. Justice Powell and Justice O'Connor took no
part in the consideration or decision of these petitions.
No. 80-2143. Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation, Petitioner
v. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. Petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
Circuit denied. Justice Powell and Justice O'Connor took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 80-2066. University of Pittsburgh, Petitioner v. Equal Employ-
ment Opportunity Commission. The motion of The American Council on
Education for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit denied.
No. 80-2073. Wilma D. Stewart, Petitioner v. Minnesota Mining and
Manufacturing Company: Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. The Chief Justice
and Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of
this petition.
No. 80-2074. Charles W. Worrell, etc., Petitioner v. United States.
The application for stay addressed to Justice Blackmun and referred to
the Court is denied. The petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Justice O'Connor
took no part in the consideration or decision of this application and peti-
tion.
No. 80-2094. John C. Weaver, Jr. and BMA of Oakland, Inc., Peti-
tioners v. Brenda Marie Payton. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the Supreme Court of California denied. Justice Brennan and Justice
Blackmun would grant certiorari.
No. 80–2114. Michael Lochiatto, et al., Petitioners v. Florida. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the District Court of Appeal of Florida,
Fourth District, denied. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall would
grant the petition for a writ of certiorari and reverse the convictions.
No. 80-2151. New Jersey, Petitioner v. Edward Joseph Ryan. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of New Jersey de-
nied.

part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Justice Stewart
(Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit beginning February 8, 1982, and end-
ing February 12, 1982, and for such further time as may be re-
quired to complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec.
294(a), is ordered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to
28 U.S.C. Sec. 295.

96
96
MONDAY OCTOBER 5, 1981
ORDER
It is ordered that the following allotment be made of the Chief Justice
and Associate Justices of this Court among the circuits, pursuant
to Title 28, United States Code, Section 42 and that such allotment
be entered of record, effective nunc pro tunc October 1, 1981, viz:
For the District of Columbia Circuit, Warren E. Burger, Chief Justice,
For the First Circuit, William J. Brennan, Jr., Associate Justice,
For the Second Circuit, Thurgood Marshall, Associate Justice,
For the Third Circuit, William J. Brennan, Jr., Associate Justice,
For the Fourth Circuit, Warren E. Burger, Chief Justice,
For the Fifth Circuit, Byron R. White, Associate Justice,
For the Sixth Circuit, Sandra Day O'Connor, Associate Justice,
For the Seventh Circuit, John Paul Stevens, Associate Justice,
For the Eighth Circuit, Harry A. Blackmun, Associate Justice,
For the Ninth Circuit, William H. Rehnquist, Associate Justice,
For the Tenth Circuit, Byron R. White, Associate Justice,
For the Eleventh Circuit, Lewis F. Powell, Jr., Associate Justice.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 80-1464. James G. Watt, Secretary of the Interior, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Energy Action Educational Foundation, et al. Argued by Mr.

respondents.

County Rural Electric Membership Corporation; and National Labor
Relations Board, Petitioner v. Malleable Iron Range Company; and

Range Company.

spondent.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1981
107
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
--
No. 80-1958. Louisiana Dairy Stabilization Board, Appellant v. Dairy
Fresh Corporation and Dairy Fresh Ice Cream Corporation. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The
judgment is affirmed. The Chief Justice and Justice Rehnquist would
note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 81–207. New River Company, Appellant v. David W. Robinson,
etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81–240. Willard A. Morris, etc., et al., Appellants v. Thomas P.
Mathers, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 81-292. Dora Lillian Russum, Appellant v. Estate of John R.
Russum, Sr. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Mississippi. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81-364. Merle E. Holmes, et al., Appellants v. City of Los Ange-
les. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion.
No. 81-229. Frito-Lay, Inc., Appellant v. Wisconsin Labor and In-
dustry Review Commission and James R. Lyons. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of Wisconsin. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 81-5257. James Charles Scott, Appellant v. Virginia. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

108
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1981
CERTIORARI -- SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-247. Alabama, Petitioner v. Wayne Eugene Ritter. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama. The motion
of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Alabama for further con-
sideration in light of Reed v. State, So.2d — (Ala. 1981).

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Richard Weiss, et al., Applicant v. Marshall Field & Com-
pany, et al. The application to direct the Clerk to file petitioners' appli-
cation for an extension of time presented to Justice Stevens and by him
referred to the Court is denied. Justice Stevens took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this application.
No. A-210. Michigan, Applicant v. Leslie Rucinski. The application
for stay of state court proceedings addressed to Justice Rehnquist and
referred to the Court is denied. Justice Rehnquist and Justice O'Con-
nor would grant this application.
No. A-226. H. Byron Gaar, Jr. and Monette Gaar, Applicants v.
Commissioner of Internal Revenue. The application for stay addressed
to Justice Brennan and referred to the Court is denied.

of Consumers' Counsel Senior Citizens Coalition, et al. The application
for stay of execution and enforcement of the judgment of the Supreme
Court of Ohio presented to Justice White and by him referred to the
Court is denied.
No. A-266. Marian W. Zacharski, Applicant v. United States. The
application for pre-trial release addressed to Justice Brennan and re-
ferred to the Court is denied.
No. D-237. In the Matter of Disbarment of John D. Connaghan. Dis-
barment entered.

State of Georgia as a party defendant; and the motion for leave to file a
bill of complaint, and the supplements thereto, are all denied without
prejudice.

and in No. 80–6704.

The Court will take a recess from Monday, October 19, 1981, until

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 80-1377. Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Defense, et al.,
Petitioners v. Catholic Action of Hawaii/Peace Education Project, et al.
Argued by Mr. Solicitor General Rex E. Lee for the petitioners and by
Miss Nancy Stearns for the respondents.
No. 80-931. Charles D. Bonanno Linen Service, Inc., Petitioner v.
National Labor Relations Board, et al. Argued by Mr. Sidney A. Coven
for the petitioner, by Mr. Norton J. Come for respondent NLRB, and
by Mr. James T. Grady for respondents Teamsters Local Union No. 25,
et al.
No. 80-1350. Community Communications Company, Inc., Petitioner
v. City of Boulder, Colorado, et al. Argued by Mr. Harold R. Farrow
for the petitioner, by Mr. Thomas P. McMahon for the State of Alaska,
et al., amicus curiae, by special leave of Court, and by Mr. Jeffrey H.
Howard for the respondents.
No. 80-824. Polk County, et al., Petitioners v. Russell Richard
Dodson. Argued by Mr. Norman G. Jesse for the petitioners, by Mr.
John D. Hudson for the respondent, and by Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler for
the United States as amicus curiae, by special leave of Court.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10:00 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1981
137
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 80-2041. Jack Duckworth, Warden, Petitioner v. Isadore Ser-
rano. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam. Justice Marshall dissents.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81–240. Willard A. Morris, etc., et al., Appellants v. Thomas P.
Mathers, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. The order dismissing the appeal for want of a substan-
tial federal question is hereby vacated. The judgment of the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit is affirmed.
No. 81–268. Raymond P. Scott, et al., Appellants v. Woodrow W.
"Woody" Dumas, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of Louisiana,
First Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 81-317. David P. Weinberger, Appellant v. Florida Bar. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question.
No. 81–342. Raymond Casillas, Appellant v. S.W.I.G. and Argonaut
Insurance Company. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.

138
MONDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1981
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 80-1816. Robert F. Parratt, Warden, Petitioner v. Jesse J. Ford.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Sumner v. Mata, 449 U.S. 539 (1981).
No. 81–397. Bureau of Economic Analysis, United States Depart-
ment of Commerce, Petitioner v. Susan B. Long and Philip H. Long.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light
of the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981, Section 701, Pub. L. No.
97-34.

from the practice of law in this Court.

should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1981
No. D-251. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frederick B. Gold. It is
ordered that Frederick B. Gold, of Birmingham, Michigan, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-

not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 86 Original. State of Louisiana, Plaintiff v. State of Mississippi,
et al. It is ordered that Charles J. Meyers, Esquire, of Denver, Colo-
rado, be, and he is hereby, appointed Special Master in this case with
authority to fix the time and conditions for the filing of additional plead-
ings and to direct subsequent proceedings, and with authority to sum-
mon witnesses, issue subpoenas, and take such evidence as may be in-
troduced and such as he may deem it necessary to call for. The Master
is directed to submit such reports as he may deem appropriate.
The compensation of the Special Master, the allowances to him, the
compensation paid to his technical, steno- graphic, and clerical assis-
tants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses shall
be charged against and be borne by the parties in such proportion as the
Court hereafter may direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master becomes
vacant during a recess of Court, the Chief Justice shall have authority
to make a new designation which shall have the same effect as if origi-
nally made by the Court herein.
No. 80-1285. Carl W. Brown, Petitioner v. Earl J. Hartlage. L. Stan-
ley Chauvin, Jr., Esquire, of Louisville, Kentucky, a member of the
Bar of this Court, is invited to brief and argue this case, as amicus cu-
riae, in support of the judgment below.
No. 80-1417. Mark J. Mills, et al., Petitioners v. Rubie Rogers, et al.
The motion of respondents to dismiss the writ of certiorari or in the al-
ternative to certify certain questions to the Supreme Judicial Court of
Massachusetts is denied.
No. 80-1925. United Transportation Union, Petitioner v. Long Island
Railroad Company, et al. The motion of American Federation of Labor
and Congress of Industrial Organizations for leave to file a brief as ami-
cus curiae is granted. The motion of American Public Transit Associa-
tion for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae is de-
nied.
No. 80-5861. Kenneth Ray Williams, Petitioner v. Kenneth Ray
Lucky. The motion of petitioner to consolidate this case with No.
80-6298, Mills v. Habluetzel, is denied.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1981
157
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-337. Margaret Canady, et al., Applicants v. Lumberton City
Board of Education, et al. The application for an injunction, presented
to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court, preventing the
Board of Education and the Board of Elections from permitting resi-
dents of the three annexed areas involved in this case to vote in the
school board election is granted, pending the timely filing and dispo-
sition of a jurisdictional statement, or until appellees demonstrate com-
pliance with Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act. The Chief Justice, Jus-
tice Powell and Justice Rehnquist dissent.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1981
159
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 81-249. Carlos Chardon, individually, et al., Petitioners v. Rafael
Rivera Fernandez, et al.; and Carlos Chardon, individually, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Caspar Rodriguez Rodriguez. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted. Judgments entered below on May 8,
1981, and June 11, 1981, are reversed and the cases are remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Stevens with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 80-1894. Michael Ben-Levi, Appellant v. Sharon E. Ben-Levi.
Appeal from the Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied. Justice Blackmun would note probable jurisdiction and
set the case for oral argument.
No. 81-35. Jack Van Hyning, Appellant v. University of Alaska. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Alaska. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 81-354. James L. Pickering, Appellant v. City of Buffalo, New
York. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 81–441. Paul Marsa, Appellant v. Donald J. Wernik, Individually

160
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1981
and as the Mayor of the Borough of Metuchen, et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of New Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of ju-
risdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 81-454. Dale Julian Barsness, Appellant v. Idaho. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Idaho. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 81-5386. Hal M. Rogers, Appellant v. Larry Jinks, et al. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon.
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 81-226. Town of Hardenburgh, Ulster County, New York, et al.,
Appellants v. New York, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 81–462. Spiegel, Inc., Appellant v. George Whitaker, et ux., etc.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Washington. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81-537. Beechwood Sanitarium, etc., Appellant v. David
Axelrod, et al. Appeal from the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of
New York, Fourth Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81-503. Irving Stolberg, Appellant v. Lawrence J. Davidson, et
al. Appeal from the Superior Court of Connecticut, New Haven
County. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction..
No. 81-5400. Lacey G. Stanley, Jr., Appellant v. Sarah W. Stanley.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of North Carolina. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Jus-
tice Blackmun would dismiss the appeal for want of a properly pre-
sented federal question.
CERTIORARI - SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-5383. Robert Allen May, Petitioner v. Texas. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas for further consid-
eration in light of Adams v. Texas, 448 U.S. 38 (1980).

No.
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1981
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
161
Jeffrey Williams, et al., Petitioners v. First Federal Sav-
ings & Loan Association of Arlington, et al. The motion to direct the
Clerk to file the petition for a writ of certiorari is denied. Justice Black-
mun would deny the motion as out-of-time.
No. 78–1545. Anne B. Zipes, et al., Petitioners v. Trans World Air-
lines, Inc.; and
No. 80-951. Independent Federation of Flight Attendants, Petitioner
v. Trans World Airlines, Inc., et al. The motion of the Solicitor General
for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for di-
vided argument is denied. Justice Stevens took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this motion.
No. 80-203. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., Petitioner
v. J.J. Curran and Jacquelyn L. Curran. The motion of Rosenthal &
Company for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is denied.
No. 80-1464. James G. Watt, Secretary of the Interior, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Energy Action Educational Foundation, et al. The motion of
respondents for leave to file affidavits from officers of independent oil
companies, after argument, is denied.
No. 80-5889. John Santosky II and Annie Santosky, Petitioners v.
Bernhardt S. Kramer, Commissioner, Ulster County Department of
Social Services, et al. The motion of the Attorney General of New York
for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for di-
vided argument is denied.
No. 80-6298. Lois Mae Mills, Appellant v. Dan Habluetzel. The mo-
tion of appellee to dismiss the appeal as moot is denied.
No. 81-325. Larry Blanding, et al., Appellants v. E.M. DuBose, et
al. The motion of the Sumter County appellees to strike the brief of the
United States is denied with leave of the Sumter County appellees to
file a brief in response to the brief of the Solicitor General on or before
November 16, 1981.
No. 81-752. Hugh L. Carey, et al., Petitioners v. Malcolm Baldrige,
Secretary of Commerce, et al. The motion of petitioners to expedite
consideration of the petition for a writ of certiorari and to consolidate
this case with No. 80–1436, Baldrige v. Shapiro and with No. 80–1781,
McNichols v. Baldrige is denied.
No. 81-5634. Ricky Wayne Tison and Raymond Curtis Tison, Peti-
tioners v. Arizona. The motion of petitioners to expedite consideration
of the petition for a writ of certiorari and to consolidate this case with
No. 81-5321, Enmund v. Florida is denied.

162
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1981
APPEALS JURISDICTION POSTPONED
-
No. 81-31. California, et al., Appellants v. Grace Brethren Church,
et al.; and California, et al., Appellants v. Lutheran Church-Missouri
Synod, et al.;
No. 81-228. United States, et al., Appellants v. Grace Brethren
Church, et al.; and
No. 81-455. Grace Brethren Church, et al., Appellants v. United
States, et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the
Central District of California. Further consideration of the question of
jurisdiction is postponed to the hearing of the cases on the merits. The
cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral
argument.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

School District, Westchester County, et al., Petitioners v. Amy Row-

peals for the Second Circuit granted.

McCready. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted.

Garden State Bar Association, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the

No. 80-2070. Sumitomo Shoji America, Inc., Petitioner v. Lisa M.
Avigliano, et al.; and
No. 81-24. Lisa M. Avigliano, et al., Petitioners v. Sumitomo Shoji
America, Inc. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit are granted. The cases are con-
solidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument. The Solic-
itor General is invited to file a brief in these cases expressing the views
of the United States.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 80–767. United States, Appellant v. Edwin D. Lee. Argued by
Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace for the appellant and by Mr. Francis X.
Caiazza for the appellee.
No. 80-5727. Monty Lee Eddings, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. Argued
by Mr. Jay C. Baker for the petitioner and by Mr. David W. Lee for the
respondent.
No. 80-203. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., Petitioner
v. J.J. Curran and Jacquelyn L. Curran. Argued by Mr. Richard P.
Saslow for the petitioner, by Mr. Robert A. Hudson for the respon-
dents, and by Mr. Barry Sullivan for the Commodity Futures Trading
Commission as amicus curiae, by special leave of Court.
No. 80-757. New York Mercantile Exchange, et al., Petitioners v.
Neil Leist, Philip Smith and Incomco;
No. 80-895. Clayton Brokerage Co. of St. Louis, Inc., Petitioner v.
Neil Leist, Philip Smith and Incomco; and
No. 80-936. Heinold Commodities, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Neil
Leist, et al. Argued by Mr. William E. Hegarty for the petitioners in
80-757, by Mr. Gerard K. Sandweg, Jr. for the petitioners in 80–895
and 80-936, and by Mr. Leonard Toboroff for the respondents in each
case.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY NOVEMBER 9, 1981
189
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 80-1942. A. R. Jago, Former Superintendent, Southern Ohio
Correctional Facility, et al., Petitioners v. George D. Van Curen. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. Respon-
dent's motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Judg-
ment of the Court of Appeals reversed and case remanded to the
United States Court for the Sixth Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Opinion
by Justice Blackmun concurring in the result. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Stevens with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-1604. Donald C. Brockett, etc., Appellant v. Spokane Ar-
cades, Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. The judgment is affirmed. Dissenting opinion by the
Chief Justice with whom Justice Powell and Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 81–186. James A. McClure, United States Senator, Appellant v.
Ronald Reagan, President of the United States and Abner J. Mikva.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of Idaho.
The judgment is affirmed. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this case.
No. 81-477. Donald M. Witte, Appellant v. Bar Committee of the
Twenty-First Judicial Court, etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Missouri. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 81-5422. William J. Crane, Appellant v. B. Ross, et al. Appeal

190
MONDAY NOVEMBER 9, 1981
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 81-478. Stephen D.Rabideau, Appellant v. Attorneys Board of
Professional Responsibility of Wisconsin. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Wisconsin. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 81-524. Irene Johnson, as surviving spouse of Chester Johnson,
Appellant v. Kerr-McGee Oil Industries, Inc. Appeal from the Court of
Appeals of Arizona, Division Two. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 81–505. Joseph Caffiero, et ux., Appellants v. Board of Educa-
tion of Piscataway Township, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
New Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Justice Brennan and Justice Stevens would note probable ju-
risdiction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 81-533. Aetna Life and Casualty Company, et al., Appellants v.
Linda Young, et al. Appeal from the Superior Court of Connecticut,
Fairfield County. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 81-5433. Daniel D. Travis, Appellant v. Iowa, ex rel. Candy S.
Bishop. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Iowa. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 81-384. State Fair of Texas, Petitioner v. United States Con-
sumer Product Safety Commission; and
No. 81-555. Steck & Stapf Attractions, Inc., Petitioner v. United
States Consumer Product Safety Commission. The petitions for writs of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
granted. The judgment is vacated and the cases are remanded to the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas with
directions to dismiss as moot. United States v. Munsingwear, 340 U.S.
36 (1950).
No.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Tiffany Construction Co., Inc., Petitioner v. Bureau of
Revenue, State of New Mexico. The motion to direct the Clerk to file
the petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.

MONDAY NOVEMBER 9, 1981
191
No. 91 Original. State of California, Plaintiff v. State of West Vir-
ginia. The motion for leave to file a bill of complaint is denied. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. D-239. In the Matter of Disbarment of Francis X. Fahy. Disbar-
ment entered.
No. D-243. In the Matter of Disbarment of Donald M. Witte. Disbar-
ment entered.
No. D-252. In the Matter of Disbarment of Earl A. Rawlins. It is or-
dered that Earl A. Rawlins, of New York, New York,, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-253. In the Matter of Disbarment of C. Lee Caldwell. It is or-
dered that C. Lee Caldwell, of American Fork, Utah, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 79-1738. Richard Nixon, Petitioner v. A. Ernest Fitzgerald; and
No. 80-945. Bryce N. Harlow and Alexander P. Butterfield, Petition-
ers v. A. Ernest Fitzgerald. The motion of Orrin G. Hatch, et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The motion of National
Taxpayers Legal Fund, Inc. for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. The motion of Government Accountability Project of the Insti-
tute for Policy Studies for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted.
No. 80–1199. American Tobacco Company, et al., Petitioners v. John
Patterson, et al. The motion of petitioners for divided argument is
granted.
No. 80–1608. United States, Petitioner v. Raymond Eugene Johnson.
The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that
John F. Walter, Esquire, of Los Angeles, California, is appointed to
serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 80-1765. American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Inc., Peti-
tioner v. Hydrolevel Corporation. The motion of Stephen G. Glatzer, et
al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is denied. The motion of Na-
tional Commission for Health Certifying Agencies for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of the Solicitor General
for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for di-
vided argument is granted. The motion of National Fire Protection
Association for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae
and for additional time for oral argument is denied. The motion of
Adolph J. Ackerman for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted.

192
MONDAY NOVEMBER 9, 1981
No. 80–1925. United Transportation Union, Petitioner v. Long Island
Railroad Company, et al. The motion of National Institute of Municipal
Law Officers for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 81-547. David Diaz, et ux., et al., Petitioners v. Ronald Beyer, et
ux. The motion of petitioners to strike portions of respondents' brief in
opposition is denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 81–150. Northern Pipeline Construction Co., Appellant v. Mara-
thon Pipe Line Company and United States; and
No. 81-546. United States, Appellant v. Marathon Pipe Line Co., et
al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the District of
Minnesota. In these cases probable jurisdiction is noted. The cases are
consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.
No. 81-349. Chicago Bridge & Iron Company, Appellant v. Caterpil-
lar Tractor Co., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The
motion of Frank M. Keesling for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted. The case is set for
oral argument in tandem with No. 80-1745, F. W. Woolworth Co. v.
Taxation and Revenue Department of the State of New Mexico, and
No. 80-2015, ASARCO Inc. v. Idaho State Tax Commission. Justice
Powell and Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this motion and this case.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit granted.
No. 81-535. United States Department of State, et al., Petitioners v.

United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit
granted.
No. 81–202. National Association for the Advancement of Colored
People, et al., Petitioners v. Claiborne Hardware Company, et al. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi granted.
The case is set for oral argument in tandem with No. 81-280, General
Building Contractors Association, Inc. v. Pennsylvania, and related
cases. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of
this petition.

OPINIONS
No. 80-1070. Donna Ridgway and Prudential Insurance Company of
America, Petitioners v. Hayley D. Ridgway, et al. On writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Judicial Court of Maine. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Supreme Judicial Court of Maine for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice Powell with whom Justice
Rehnquist joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens. Justice O'Con-
nor took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 80-939. Federal Election Commission, Petitioner v. Democratic
Senatorial Campaign Committee, et al.; and
No. 80–1129. National Republican Senatorial Committee, Petitioner
Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. On writs of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther consideration in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice White. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 80-5889. John Santosky, II and Annie Santosky, Petitioners v.
Bernhardt S. Kramer, Commissioner, Ulster County Department of
Social Services, et al. Argued by Mr. Martin Guggenheim for the peti-
tioners and by Mr. Stephen Scavuzzo for the respondents, pro hac vice,
by special leave of Court.
No. 80–1345. Kaiser Steel Corporation, Petitioner v. Julius Mullins,
et al. Argued by Mr. A. Douglas Melamed for the petitioner, by Mr.
Stephen J. Pollak for the respondents, and by Ms. Barbara E. Etkind
for the United States as amicus curiae by special leave of Court.

210
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 10, 1981
No. 80-1577. City of Mesquite, Appellant v. Aladdin's Castle, Inc.
Argued by Mr. Elland Archer for the appellant and by Mr. Philip W.
Tone for the appellee.
No. 80–1576. Princeton University and New Jersey, Appellants v.
Chris Schmid. Argued by Mr. Nicholas deB. Katzenbach for the appel-
lants and by Mr. Sanford Levinson for the appellee.
Adjourned until Monday, November 16, 1981 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1981
211
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 80-2077. William Leeke, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Melvin Lee
Timmerman, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Motion of respondents
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment reversed on the basis of the decision in Linda R.S.
v. Richard D., 410 U.S. 614 (1973) and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Mar-
shall and Justice Blackmun join.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-68. Cindy Foret, Appellant v. United Gas Pipeline Company,
Inc. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Cir-
cuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the pa-
pers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 81-561. Frank William Gay, et al., Appellants v. Eighth Judicial
District Court of the State of Nevada, etc., et al. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of Nevada. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 81-5164. Alfred M. Strickland, Appellant v. Baltimore City De-
partment of Social Services. Appeal from the Court of Special Appeals
of Maryland. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
No. 81-616. William J. Gedeon, Appellant v. Carrolyn L. Gedeon,

212
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1981
etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Colorado. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81–134. Willie Powell, Petitioner v. Elizabeth Powell. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Third Appel-
late District. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Court of Appeal of
California, Third Appellate District, for further consideration in light of
McCarty v. McCarty, 453 U.S. — (1981).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-362. Kentucky Association for Retarded Citizens, Inc., et al.
Applicants v. Peter Conn, Secretary, Kentucky Department for Human
Resources, et al. The application for a stay of the order of the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, case No. 80-3560, entered
October 8, 1981, presented to Justice O'Connor and by her referred to
the Court, is denied.
No. A-392. Donald E. Cantrell, et al., Applicants v. Florida. The
application for stay addressed to Justice Marshall and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. A-414. Dewey Eugene Coleman, Applicant v. Montana. The
application for stay of execution and enforcement of the sentence of
death addressed to Justice Marshall and referred to the Court is de-
nied. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, and Justice Stevens would
grant the application. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration.
or decision of this application.

tioners v. Peter Shapiro, Essex County Executive; and

merce, et al. The motion of petitioners in No. 80-1781 to divide oral ar-

No. 80-1640. United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, et al.,

No. 80-1656. Metropolitan Edison Company, et al., Petitioners v.
People Against Nuclear Energy, et al. The motion of petitioners to de-

pense with printing the joint appendix is granted.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1981
231
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
--
No. 81-335. Sea Ranch Association, et al., Appellants v. California
Coastal Commission, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of California. The judgment of the
United States District Court for the Northern District of California is
vacated. The case is remanded to that court in order that it may con-
sider whether the case is moot in light of the enactment of California
Public Resources Code Sec. 30610.6.
Х



(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1981
233
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 81-451. Ralph Hathorn, et al., Applicants v. Mrs. Bobby Lovorn,
et al. The application to stay the election scheduled for December 5,
1981, presented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court, is
denied. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Jus-
tice Stevens would grant the application.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1981
235
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
PER CURIAM
No. 81-271. Edward Cooper, City Attorney of Santa Ana, California,
Petitioner v. Mitchell Brothers' Santa Ana Theater, etc., et al. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth
Appellate District. Petition for writ of certiorari granted limited to
question 2 presented in the petition. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeal for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Stevens.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-6692. William Durwood Busbee, Appellant v. Texas. Appeal
from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction.
No. 81-404. Court House Plaza Company, Appellant v. City of Palo
Alto, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, First Appel-
late District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
No. 81-467. Ford Motor Credit Company and Yates Ford, Inc., Ap-
pellants v. Arnulfo R. Zapata. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Texas. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the pa-
pers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
No. 81-488. Ford Motor Credit Company and Tradewinds Ford
Sales, Inc., Appellants v. Don B. Caskey, et al. Appeal from the Su-

236
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1981
preme Court of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 81-589. Forrest McCluney, Appellant v. Jos. Schlitz Brewing
Co. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Cir-
cuit. The judgment is affirmed. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 81-669. Shepherd Construction Co., Inc., et al., Appellants v.
Georgia. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI -SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-2086. East Baton Rouge Parish School Board, et al., Petition-
ers v. Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, Realm of Louisiana, et al. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Equal
Access to Justice Act, Pub. L. No. 96-481, Sec. 201-08.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No.- Forty-Eight Insulations, Inc., Petitioner v. Liberty Mutual
Insurance Company and Travelers Indemnity of Rhode Island. The mo-
tion to direct the Clerk to file the cross-petition for a writ of certiorari is
denied.
No. . Grand Traverse Area Sport Fishing Association, Peti-
tioner v. United States, et al. The motion to direct the Clerk to file the
petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.
No. A-309. Alex Melvin Wade, Jr., Applicant v. Texas. The appli-
cation for bail addressed to the Chief Justice and referred to the Court
is denied.
No. A-393. Carmine Romano, et al., Applicants v. United States.
The application for bail addressed to Justice O'Connor and referred to
the Court is denied.
No. D-93. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jack Alan Hendler. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-254. In the Matter of Disbarment of Walter Carl Wencke. It is
ordered that Walter Carl Wencke, of Del Mar, California, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1981
237
No. 27 Original. State of Ohio, Plaintiff v. Commonwealth of Ken-
tucky; and
No. 81 Original. Commonwealth of Kentucky, Plaintiff v. State of In-
diana, et al. The motion of Dorothy Cole, et al. for leave to intervene is
referred to the Special Master.
No. 65 Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico. It
is ordered that the order heretofore entered on November 11, 1975,
which appeared in 423 U.S. 942, is amended to read as follows: It is or-
dered that the Honorable Jean Sala Breitenstein, Senior Judge for the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit, be appointed
Special Master in this case with authority to fix the time and conditions
for the filing of additional pleadings and to direct subsequent proceed-
ings, and with authority to summon witnesses, issue subpoenas, and
take such evidence as may be introduced and such as he may deem it
necessary to call for. The Master is directed to submit such reports as
he may deem appropriate.
The Master shall be allowed his actual expenses. The allowances to
him, the compensation paid to his legal, technical, stenographic, and
clerical assistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper
expenses shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such
proportion as the Court may hereafter direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master in this case
becomes vacant during a recess of the Court, the Chief Justice shall
have authority to make a new designation which shall have the same
effect as if originally made by the Court.
The motion of the United States for leave to intervene is referred to
the Special Master. (For earlier order herein, see 421 U.S. 927.)
No. 89 Original. State of California, ex rel. State Lands Commission,
Plaintiff v. United States. The motion of the Solicitor General for judg-
ment on the pleadings is set for oral argument in due course. The defen-
dant shall have forty-five days within which to file the opening brief.
The brief of the plaintiff shall be filed thirty days after receipt of the
opening brief.
No. 80-702. United States, Petitioner v. State of New Mexico, et al.
The motion of the Solicitor General to permit George W. Jones, Esquire
to present oral argument pro hac vice is granted.
No. 80-1538. James Plyler, Superintendent of the Tyler Independent
School District and its Board of Trustees, et al., Appellants v. J. and R.
Doe, etc., et al.; and

238
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1981
No. 80–1934. Texas, et al., Appellants v. Certain Named and Un-
named Undocumented Alien Children, et al. The motion of appellants
for divided argument is granted.
No. 80-1765. American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Inc., Peti-
tioner v. Hydrolevel Corporation. The motion of ECOS Electronics
Corporation for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 80–1832. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Appellant v.
Jagdish Rai Chadha, et al.;
No. 80-2170. United States House of Representatives, Petitioner v.
Immigration and Naturalization Service, et al.; and
No. 80-2171. United States Senate, Petitioner v. Immigration and
Naturalization Service, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for di-
vided argument and for additional time for oral argument is granted
and an additional thirty minutes are allotted for oral argument.
No. 80-2177. Marjorie Lehman, etc., Petitioner v. Lycoming County
Children's Services Agency. The motion of petitioner to dispense with
printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 81-440. Insurance Corporation of Ireland, Ltd., et al., Petition-
ers v. Compagnie Des Bauxites de Guinee. The motion of respondent
Compagnie Des Bauxites De Guinee to recall the writ of certiorari is
denied.
No. 81-523. Container Corporation of America, Appellant v. Fran-
chise Tax Board. The motion of appellant to note probable jurisdiction
and to hear case in tandem with No. 81-349, Chicago Bridge & Iron Co.
v. Caterpillar Tractor Co.; No. 80-2015, ASARCO, Inc. v. Idaho State
Tax Commission; and No. 80-1745, F.W. Woolworth Co. v. Taxation
and Revenue Department of New Mexico is denied. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 81-5114. Delbert Lee Tibbs, Petitioner v. Florida. The motion
for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Louis R.
Beller, Esquire of Miami Beach, Florida, is appointed to serve as coun-
sel for the petitioner in this case.
No. 81-5534. John E. Rennie, et al., Petitioners v. Ann Klein, Com-
missioner, Department of Human Services, et al. The motion of peti-
tioners for expedited consideration and to set case in tandem with No.
80-1417, Mills v. Rogers is denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 81-613. Joy Sporhase and Delmer Moss, etc., Appellants v. Ne-
braska, ex rel. Paul L. Douglas, Attorney General. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of Nebraska. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.

Bureau of Revenue of New Mexico. Appeal from the Court of Appeals
of New Mexico. The motion of Navajo Tribe of Indians for leave to file a

noted.

of Wine & Spirits Wholesalers of America, Inc., et al. for leave to file a
brief as amici curiae is granted. The petitions for writs of certiorari to
the Court of Appeal of California, Third Appellate District, are
granted. The cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted.
for oral argument.

Sixth Circuit granted.

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Justice Stew-
art (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit beginning February 24, 1982, and end-
ing February 26, 1982, and for such further time as may be required to
complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec. 294(a), is or-
dered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec.
295.

254
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1981

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 79-1738. Richard Nixon, Petitioner v. A. Ernest Fitzgerald; and
No. 80-945. Bryce N. Harlow and Alexander P. Butterfield, Peti-
tioners v. A. Ernest Fitzgerald. One hour and twenty minutes allowed
for oral argument. Argued by Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr. for petitioner
Nixon, by Mr. Elliot L. Richardson for petitioners Harlow and
Butterfield, and by Mr. John E. Nolan, Jr. for the respondent.
No. 80-5887. Richard H. White, Petitioner v. New Hampshire De-
partment of Employment Security, et al. Argued by Mr. E. Richard
Larson for the petitioner and by Mr. Marc R. Scheer for the respon-
dents.
No. 80–1188. James Edgar, Appellant v. Mite Corporation and Mite
Holdings, Inc. One hour and thirty minutes allowed for oral argument.
Argued by Mr. Russell C. Grimes, Jr. for the appellant, by Mr. Eugene
D. Berman for the State of New York as amicus curiae, by special
leave of Court, by Mr. Richard W. Hulbert for the appellees, and by
Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro for the S.E.C. as amicus curiae, by special
leave of Court.
Adjourned until Tuesday, December 1, 1981 at 10 o'clock.



(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1981
263
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 80-1464. James G. Watt, Secretary of the Interior, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Energy Action Educational Foundation, et al. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Colum-
bia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice O'Connor.
No. 80-427. Fair Assessment in Real Estate Association, Inc., et al.,
Petitioners v. Gene McNary, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring
in the judgment with whom Justice Marshall, Justice Stevens and Jus-
tice O'Connor join.
No. 80-1377. Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Defense, et al.,
Petitioners v. Catholic Action of Hawaii/Peace Education Project, et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit with instructions to rein-
state the judgment of dismissal entered by the United States District
Court for the District of Hawaii. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Opinion
by Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment with whom Justice
Brennan joins.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 80-1538. James Plyler, Superintendent of the Tyler Independent
School District and its Board of Trustees, et al., Appellants v. J. and R.
Doe, etc., et al.; and
No. 80-1934. Texas, et al., Appellants v. Certain Named and Un-
named Undocumented Alien Children, et al. Argued by Mr. Richard
L. Arnett for the appellants in 80-1934, by Mr. John C. Hardy for the
appellants in 80-1538, by Mr. Peter A. Schey for the appellees in
80-1934, and by Mr. Peter D. Roos for the appellees in 80-1538.

TUESDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1981
No. 80-988. Havens Realty Corporation, et al., Petitioners v. Sylvia
Coleman, et al. Argued by Mr. Everett G. Allen, Jr. for the petitioners
and by Ms. Vanessa Ruiz for the respondents.
No. 80-1240. Michael P. Lane, Director, Illinois Department of Cor-
rections, Petitioner v. Lawrence Williams and Oscar Southall. Argued
by Mr. Michael B. Weinstein for the petitioner and by Ms. Martha A.
Mills for the respondents.

sioner of Internal Revenue. Argued by Mr. James D. St. Clair for the
petitioners and by Mr. Stuart A. Smith for the respondent.

OPINIONS
No. 80-2049. George A. Ralston, Warden, Petitioner v. John Carroll
Robinson. On writ of certiorari to the the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Marshall. Opinion by Justice Powell concurring in the judg-
ment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Bren-
nan and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 80-885. National Labor Relations Board, Petitioner v. Hendricks.
County Rural Electric Membership Corporation; and National Labor
Relations Board, Petitioner v. Malleable Iron Range Company; and
No. 80-1103. Hendricks County Rural Electric Membership Corpora-
tion, Petitioner v. National Labor Relations Board. On writs of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. In
No. 80-885, judgment of the Court of Appeals, case No. 80–1283, is re-
versed insofar as enforcement of the Board's order was denied and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit with direction to enter an order enforcing the Board's order and
judgment of the Court of Appeals, in case No. 79–1991, is reversed and
case remanded to to United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. In No. 80-1103, the writ of certiorari is dismissed as improvi-
dently granted. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Opinion by Justice Powell
concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom The Chief Justice,
Justice Rehnquist and Justice O'Connor join.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1981
267
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.'
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
"
No. 81-5280. Allen Eugene LeMay, Appellant v. Tennessee. Appeal
from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Tennessee, Middle Division. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 81-5566. Daniel R. Denardo, Appellant v. Patrick Murphy, etc.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Alaska. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-447. In Re Charles P. Myles, Applicant. The application for
writ of habeas corpus addressed to the Chief Justice and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. 89 Original. State of California, ex rel. State Lands Commission,
Plaintiff v. United States. The motion of California for summary judg-
ment is consolidated for oral argument with the motion of the United
States for judgment on the pleadings. Opening briefs on both motions
shall be filed within forty-five days from November 30, 1981. Reply
briefs, if any, may be filed within thirty days of receipt of the opening
briefs.
No. 80–2116. William Archie Williams, Petitioner v. United States.
The order entered November 9, 1981, is amended to read as follows:
The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted limited to Questions 3 and
4 presented by the petition.
No. 80-2205. Morgan M. Finley, Clerk of the Circuit Court of Cook
County, Illinois, Petitioner v. Toni Murray. The motion for appoint-
ment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that John S. Elson, Es-
quire, of Chicago, Illinois, is appointed to serve as counsel for the re-
spondent in this case.

The motion of Alliance of American Insurers for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Hartford Accident & Indem-
nity Company for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The
motion of Keene Corporation for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is

274
MONDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1981
granted. The motion of Armstrong World Industries, Inc., et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The motions of American
Home Assurance Company, et al. for leave to file briefs as amici curiae
is granted. The motion of petitioner in No. 81-198 to defer consider-
ation of the petitions for writs of certiorari is denied. Petitions for writs
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit
denied. Justice Brennan and Justice O'Connor took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of these motions and these petitions.

Company, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Peti-

Fifth Circuit denied. Justice Brennan and Justice O'Connor took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion and this petition.

Harris. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma paupe-
ris is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 81-499. Mobil Oil Corporation, Petitioner v. United States De-
partment of Energy, et al. The motion of Texas City Refining, Inc. for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The petition for a writ
of certiorari to the Temporary Emergency Court of Appeals of the
United States is denied. Justice Brennan would grant certiorari. The
order heretofore entered by Justice Brennan on September 3, 1981 is
vacated.

Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for

No. 81-816. Massachusetts Department of Public Welfare, et al., Pe-
titioners v. Newfield House, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit denied. Justice
White and Justice O'Connor would grant certiorari.
No. 81-5478. Kenneth Hardy, Petitioner v. Georgia. The petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia is denied. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall.

No. 80–689. Gary E. Widmar, et al., Petitioners v. Clark Vincent, et
al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Powell. Opinion
by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Justice White.
No. 80-848. Piper Aircraft Company, Petitioner v. Gaynell Reyno,
Personal Representative of the Estate of William Fehilly, et al.; and
No. 80-883. Hartzell Propeller, Inc., Petitioner v. Gaynell Reyno,
Personal Representative of the Estate of William Fehilly, et al. On
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further consideration in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Opinion by Justice White concur-
ring in part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ste-
vens with whom Justice Brennan joins. Justice Powell took no part in
the decision of these cases. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of these cases.
