(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1981
287
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Stevens, and
Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 81-17. David R. Harris, Superintendent, Green Haven Correc-
tional Facility, Petitioner v. Jose Rivera. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-367. Marvin Neilson, Appellant v. Oklahoma. Appeal from
the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 81-5499. Ian Cohen, Appellant v. New York City Board of Edu-
cation, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 81-734. Central Avenue News, Inc., et al., Appellants v. City of
Minot, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of North Dakota. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81-5621. Carl A. Johnson, Appellant v. Aetna Casualty & Surety
Company of Hartford, Connecticut, et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Wyoming. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.

288
MONDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1981
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-176. Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, Pe-
titioner v. Security Bancorp and Security National Bank. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated as moot and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit with instructions to remand the
case to the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to va-
cate the administrative decision.
No. 81-272. Max LaValley, et al., Petitioners v. Northwood Apart-
ments. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Fair Assessment in Real Estate Association, Inc. v.
McNary, 454 U. S. (1981).
-
No. 81-5134. Woodrow Barksdale, II, Petitioner v. Frank Black-
burn, Warden. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The order of dismissal is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
for further consideration in light of the position presently asserted by
the Attorny General of Louisiana and the District Attorney for the Par-
ish of Orleans in their memorandum filed November 2, 1981.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-479. Cappaert Enterprises, Applicant v. Citizens and South-
ern International Bank of New Orleans. The application for stay ad-
dressed to Justice Marshall and referred to the Court is denied.
No. 77 Original. State of Tennessee, Plaintiff v. State of Arkansas.
On Bill of Complaint. It is ordered, adjudged and decreed that:
1. The boundary line between the States of Tennessee and Arkansas
in the area in controversy is fixed as geodetically described in Exhibit
A, and as shown on Appendix E to the Special Master's Report filed
with this Court on April 13, 1981. Said Exhibit E is incorporated by
reference.
2. The costs of this proceeding shall be divided equally between the
parties.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1981
289
No. 83 Original. State of Maryland, et al., Plaintiffs v. State of Loui-
siana. The motion of the Special Master to be discharged is granted and
it is ordered that John F. Davis, Esquire, is discharged as Special Mas-
ter. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 80-1002. Board of Education of the Hendrick Hudson Central
School District, Westchester County, et al., Petitioners v. Amy Row-

mit American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Orga-
nizations to present oral argument as amicus curiae is denied.

rated, Petitioner v. Louis Swint and Willie Johnson, etc.; and
No. 80-1193. United Steelworkers of America, AFL-CIO, et al., Pe-

tioners for divided argument is denied.
No. 80-1798. Woelke & Romero Framing, Inc., Petitioner v. Na-
tional Labor Relations Board, et al.;
No. 80-1808. Pacific Northwest Chapter of the Associated Builders &
Contractors, Inc., Petitioner v. National Labor Relations Board, et al.;
and
No. 81–91. Oregon-Columbia Chapter, The Associated General Con-
tractors of America, Inc., Petitioner v. National Labor Relations
Board, et al. The motion of the parties for divided argument and for
additional time for oral argument is granted and a total of one hour and
twenty minutes is allotted for oral argument to be divided as follows:
Woelke & Romero Framing, Inc. - 20 minutes; National Labor Rela-
tions Board - 20 minutes; respondent unions - 20 minutes; petitioners in
case Nos. 80-1808 and 81-91 - 20 minutes.
No. 80-2150. Donald Finnegan, et al., Petitioners v. Harold D. Leu,
et al. The motion of Association for Union Democracy, et al. for leave to
file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 80-2182. Inwood Laboratories, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Ives
Laboratories, Inc.; and

290
MONDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1981
No. 81–11. Darby Drug Co., Inc., Petitioners v. Ives Laboratories,
Inc. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae and for additional time for oral argument is
granted and ten additional minutes are allotted for that purpose. The
motion of petitioners for divided argument is denied.
No. 81-1. Goldsboro Christian Schools, Inc., Petitioner v. United
States; and
No. 81-3. Bob Jones University, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of Goldsboro Christian Schools, Inc. for divided oral argument
and for additional time for oral argument is denied. The motion of Trent
Lott for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae in No. 81-3 is granted.
No. 81–349. Chicago Bridge & Iron Company, Appellant v. Caterpil-
lar Tractor Co., et al. The motion of appellees for additional time for
oral argument is denied. The motion of appellees for divided argument
is granted. Justice Powell, and Justice O'Connor took no part in the
consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 81-614. Danny L. Griffin, Petitioner v. Oceanic Contractors, Inc.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed further herein as a seaman
is granted.
No. 81-792. Leslie R. Hinds, et al., Petitioners v. Consolidated Rail
Corporation and United States. The motion of petitioners to expedite
consideration of the petition and set the case for argument in tandem
with No. 81-213, Schweiker v. Hogan is denied.
No. 81-954. First Pentecostal Church, Petitioner v. United States.
The application for stay and recall of mandate presented to Justice
Blackmun and by him referred to the Court is denied.
No. 81-1068. George H. Ryan, et al., Appellants v. Earl Neil Otto, et
al. The appellees are directed to file motions to dismiss or affirm on or
before December 31, 1981. In all other respects, the motion of appel-
lants to expedite is denied. Justice Marshall dissents and would deny
the motion to expedite.
No. 81-5114. Delbert Lee Tibbs, Petitioner v. Florida. The motion of
Michael A. Palecki to permit Deborah A. Osmond, of Tampa, Florida,
to present oral argument pro hac vice is granted.

OPINIONS
No. 80-824. Polk County, et al., Petitioners v. Russell Richard
Dodson. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further consideration in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice Powell. Concurring opinion by Chief Jus-
tice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun.
No. 80-737. Citizens Against Rent Control/Coalition for Fair Hous-
ing, et al., Appellants v. City of Berkeley, California, et al. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of California. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court of California for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Chief Justice
Burger. Concurring opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Justice
Marshall concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Blackmun and
Justice O'Connor concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Justice White.
☑
Adjourned until Monday, January 11, 1982 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1982
303
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 80-1565. Central Trust Company, Rochester, N.Y., Petitioner v.
Officials Creditors' Committee of Geiger Enterprises, Inc., et al. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ste-
vens with whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 80–6845. Donald G. Boag, Petitioner v. Ellis MacDougall, Direc-
tor, Arizona Department of Corrections. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Concurring opinion by Jus-
tice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom the
Chief Justice and Justice White join.
No. 81-23. Terrell Don Hutto, Director, Virginia State Department
of Corrections, et al., Petitioners v. Roger Trenton Davis. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Western District of Virginia with
instructions to dismiss respondent's habeas corpus petition. Opinion per
curiam. Opinion by Justice Powell concurring in the judgment. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and
Justice Stevens join.
No. 81-255. Raymond J. Donovan, Secretary of Labor, et al., Appel-
lants v. Richland County Association for Retarded Citizens. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judg-

304
MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1982
ment and opinion of the Court of Appeals is vacated. The appeal is dis-
missed and the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
curiam. Opinion by Justice Powell concurring in part and dissenting in
part with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
No. 81–325. Larry Blanding, et al., Appellants v. E.M. DuBose, et
al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
South Carolina. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States District Court for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. The Chief Justice concurs in
the judgment. Concurring opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom
Justice Powell joins.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 80-970. George Firestone, Secretary of State of Florida, et al.,
Appellants v. Let's Help Florida, et al. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The judgment is affirmed.
No. 81-1068. George H. Ryan, et al., Appellants v. Earl Neil Otto, et
al.; and
No. 81-1077. Robert McClory, Appellant v. Ear Neil Otto, et al. Ap-
peals from the United States District Court for the Northern District of
Illinois. The judgment is affirmed.
No. 80-1945. Armed Forces Cooperative Insuring Association, Ap-
pellant v. Department of Insurance, State of Wyoming. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Wyoming. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. Justice Blackmun would postpone further
consideration of the question of jurisdiction to a hearing of the case on
the merits.
No. 80-2056. F/V American Eagle, etc., Appellant v. Alaska. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Alaska. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question. Justice Brennan and Justice Stevens
would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 81-219. First West Virginia Bancorp, Inc., et al., Appellants v.
Security National Bank & Trust Co., et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Appeals of West Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question.
No. 81-504. John K. Sjong, Appellant v. Alaska. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of Alaska. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substan-
tial federal question.

MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1982
305
No. 81-5640. James Spikes, Appellant v. Ohio. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 81-293. Larry Van Emmerik, etc., Appellant v. William J.
Janklow, etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of South Dakota.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice White with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
No. 81-712. Mary Lou Blalock and Michael Coy Blalock, Appellants
v. Florida. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Justice Brennan would postpone fur-
ther consideration of the question of jurisdiction to a hearing of the case
on the merits.
No. 81-743. William Daniel Cowgill, et al., Appellants v. Florida. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Justice Brennan would postpone further consider-
ation of the question of jurisdiction to a hearing of the case on the mer-
its.
No. 81-782. Jim Wall, III, William Gregory Wall and Danny Russell,
Appellants v. Florida. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Justice Brennan would
postpone further consideration of the question of jurisdiction to a hear-
ing of the case on the merits.
No. 81-5368. Paul Cummings and Doris Cummings, Appellants v.
Town of Oakland, Maine. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court of
Maine. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied. Justice Brennan, Justice White and Justice Powell
would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 81-5641. Rocco Fischetti, Appellant v. Joseph Ascione. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 81-5729. Frank H. Severa, Appellant v. Board of Review of New
Jersey, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 81-5709. Melody Wittner, Appellant v. Cass County Welfare De-
partment, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Justice Brennan and Justice
Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argu-
ment.

and United States Parole Commission. The application for stay ad-
dressed to Justice Brennan and referred to the Court is denied.

cation for bail addressed to Justice Brennan and referred to the Court is
denied.

application for bail addressed to Justice Marshall and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. 9 Original. United States, Plantiff v. State of Louisiana, et al.
The Final Accounting of the United States, the Corrected Final Ac-
counting of the United States and the Final Accounting of Louisiana are
ordered filed. The Objections to the Final Accountings are referred to
the Special Master. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration
or decision of this order.

Patterson, et al. The motion of Solicitor General to permit David A.
Strauss, Esquire to present oral argument pro hac vice is granted.

Labor Relations Board, et al. The motion of petitioner for expedited
consideration of petition for rehearing is denied.

denied.

tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
denied.

would grant certiorari.
No. 81-861. Florida, Petitioner v. Robert Lewis Buford. The motion
of respondent Robert Lewis Buford for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Florida denied. Justice O'Connor would grant certiorari.
No. 81-882. Johns-Manville Corporation, et al., Petitioners v. John
W. White, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Justice Brennan took
no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 81–903. Lakewood Bank and Trust Company, Petitioner v. Har-
old C. Abramson. The motion of American Land Title Association for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Federal
National Mortgage Assn. for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. The motion of Federal Land Bank of Texas, et al. for leave to
file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 81–904. Rockwell International Corporation, et al., Petitioners v.
City of New York, et al. The motion of Chamber of Commerce of the
United States for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit denied.
No. 81–929. Champlin Petroleum Company, Petitioner v. King &
King Enterprises, dba King Gas & Oil, and Carl R. King, dba King Gas
& Oil. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Tenth Circuit denied. Justice White dissenting: Because
the decision of the Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit in this case
conflicts with the decision of the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
in Carpa, Inc. v. Ward Foods, Inc., 567 F.2d 1316 (1978), I would grant
the petition for certiorari. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this petition.
No. 81-5454. Anthony Anthon, Petitioner v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Tenth Circuit denied. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall would
grant certiorari.
No. 81-5496. Alfred Witherspoon, Petitioner v. Florida. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Justice Bren-
nan and Justice Marshall would grant certiorari.

MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1982
327
No. 81-5855. Robert Lewis Buford, Petitioner v. Florida. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 81-5462. Betty Lou Martin, Petitioner v. Richard S. Schweiker,
Secretary of Health and Human Services. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit denied.
Justice White dissenting: Because the decision of the Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit in this case conflicts with the decision of the Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Rosenberg v. Richardson, 538 F.2d
487 (1976), I would grant the petition for certiorari.
HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 81-5772. In Re Thomas H. F. Irving, Petitioner; and
No. 81-5823. In Re Jimmie Lee Allen, Petitioner. Petitions for writs.
of habeas corpus denied.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 81-5455. In Re Ronald Stephen Reynolds, Petitioner;
No. 81-5595. In Re James Piatt, Petitioner;
No. 81-5660. In Re Jimmie Lee Allen, Petitioner;
No. 81-5695. In Re Ron A. Mitskus, Petitioner; and
No. 81-5710. In Re Pasquale Charles Marzano, Petitioner. The peti-
tions for writs of mandamus are denied.
No. 81-1004. In Re Giles Galahad. Petition for writ of mandamus
and/or prohibition denied.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JANUARY 12, 1982
339
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 80–1121. United States, Petitioner v. Joseph J. Clark, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Claims. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Claims for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
O'Connor.
No. 80-965. Texaco, Inc., et al., Appellants v. Louise F. Short, et al.;
and
No. 80-1018. Eden H. Pond, Edna H. Bobe and Consolidation Coal
Company, Appellants v. Ulysses G. Walden, Jr., et al. Appeals from
the Supreme Court of Indiana. Judgments affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice
White, Justice Marshall, and Justice Powell join.
No. 80–327. Valley Forge Christian College, Petitioner v. Americans
United for Separation of Church and State, Inc., et al. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom
Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Stevens.
No. 80-931. Charles D. Bonanno Linen Service, Inc., Petitioner v.
National Labor Relations Board, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice White. Concurring opinion by Justice Ste-
vens. Dissenting opinion by Chief Justice Burger with whom Justice
Rehnquist joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom
Justice Powell joins.
No. 80-990. Clarence E. Cabell, etc., et al., Appellants v. Jose Cha-
vez-Salido, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Central District of California. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the United States District Court for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Mar-
shall, and Justice Stevens join.

340
TUESDAY, JANUARY 12, 1982
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 80-6298. Lois Mae Mills, Appellant v. Dan Habluetzel. Argued
by Mr. Michael S. Mankins for the appellant and by Ms. Lola L. Bonner
for the appellee.
No. 80-2134. Foremost Insurance Company, et al., Petitioners v.

Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS
No. 80–1345. Kaiser Steel Corporation, Petitioner v. Julius Mullins et
al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun
join.
No. 80-1251. United States, Petitioner v. Vogel Fertilizer Company.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Claims. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Blackmun with whom Justice White joins.
No. 80-1350. Community Communications Company, Inc., Petitioner
v. City of Boulder, Colorado, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan.
Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Rehnquist with whom Chief Justice Burger and Justice O'Connor join.
Justice White took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 80-1349. Washington, Petitioner v. Neil Martin Chrisman. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Washington. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Chief
Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom Justice
Brennan and Justice Marshall join.

342
WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 13, 1982
No. 80–1576. Princeton University and New Jersey, Appellants v.
Chris Schmid. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. Appeal
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Opinion per curiam. Justice Brennan
took no part in the consideration or of this case.
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Justice Marshall is absent but reserves the right to participate
in today's arguments on the basis of the entire record, briefs, and the
tape recording of the oral arguments."

lants v. Idaho, et al.; and

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,

The Chief Justice said:

filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-1575. Isabelle Craig, Sole Heir-at-Law and Successor in In-
terest to Carl M. Worth, and Shell Oil Company, Appellants v. John E.
Bickel, et al.; and
No. 80–1624. Myrtle Larsen, et al., Appellants v. H. John Van
Slooten. Appeals from the Supreme Court of Michigan. The appeals are
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81–600. James E. Hernandez, Appellant v. City of Lafayette,
Louisiana, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion.
No. 81-961. Vigilant Insurance Company, Appellant v. Lydia
Pitoniak. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81–1078. Bernard A. Geller, Appellant v. Merit Systems Protec-
tion Board, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the First Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-1498. National Labor Relations Board, Petitioner v. H & D,
Inc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Charles D. Bonanno Linen Service,
Inc. v. NLRB, 454 U.S. (1982).

346
MONDAY, JANUARY 18, 1982
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-570. Wilcomb E. Washburn, Applicant v. Lelia K. Washburn.
The application for stay addressed to Justice O'Connor and referred to
the Court is denied.
No. A-583. Vincenzo Melia, Applicant v. United States, et al. The
application for recall and stay of mandate presented to Justice Marshall
and by him referred to the Court is denied.
No. A-617. United States, Applicant v. Undetermined Quantities of
Articles. The application for stay of the orders of the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Southern District of Florida, Case Nos. 80-6400-Civ-
JLK and 80-6407-Civ-JLK, entered November 13, 1981, presented to
Justice Powell and by him referred to the Court, is granted pending fi-
nal disposition of the appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit.
No. D-255. In the Matter of Disbarment of James R. Holman. It is
ordered that James R. Holman, of Tempe Arizona, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-256. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank D. DeFrancis. It is
ordered that Frank D. DeFrancis, of Dayton Ohio, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

gument as amicus curiae is denied. The motion of appellees to recon-

nied. Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor took no part in the
consideration or decision of these motions.

ages and related expenses is denied.

titioners v. Holy Spirit Association of the Unification of World Chris-
tianity. The motion of respondent to modify the order entered by the
Chief Justice on November 17, 1981 is granted and the order is vacated
insofar as it relates to the "35 congressionally generated documents." In
all other respects, the order of the Chief Justice entered November 17,
1981 is continued pending this Court's final disposition of the petition
for a writ of certiorari.

ham, et al., Petitioners v. Associated General Contractors of America,
Alabama Branch, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Su-
preme Court of Alabama denied. Justice Brennan would grant certio-
rari.
HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 81-5612. In Re Roger Aldworth Beach, Petitioner;
No. 81-5859. In Re Ronald M. King, Sr., Petitioner; and
No. 81-5869. In Re Joseph Clayborne, Petitioner. Petitions for writs
of habeas corpus denied.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 81-5761. In Re Joe Widemon, Petitioner. Petition for writ of
mandamus denied.
No. 81-5880. In Re William D. Paul, Petitioner. Petition for writ of
mandamus and/or prohibition denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 81-5585. Joseph Edward Lunz, Petitioner v. Anthony Jimenez,
et al.; and
No. 81-5627. Richard P. Williams, Petitioner v. United States. Peti-
tions for rehearing are denied.
No. 80-2074. Charles W. Worrell, etc., Petitioner v. United States.
Petition for rehearing denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this petition.
No. 81-500. M. Thora Worrell, Petitioner v. B. F. Goodrich Com-
pany. The motion for leave to file a petition for rehearing is denied.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, January 25, 1982, until
Monday, February 22, 1982.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 80-2165. James M. Murphy, District Judge, Fourth Judicial Dis-
trict of the State of Nebraska, Douglas County, Appellant v. Eugene L.
Hunt. Argued by Mr. Terry R. Schaaf for the appellant and by Mr.
Bennett G. Hornstein for the appellee.
No. 80-1556. Kenneth Cory, Controller of the State of California, et
al., Petitioners v. Mark White, Attorney General of the State of Texas,
et al. Argued by Mr. Jerome B. Falk, Jr. for the petitioners, by Mr. O.
Clayton Lilienstern for respondents Lummis, et al. and by Mr. Rick
Harrison for respondents White and Bullock.
No. 80-1045. Jacksonville Bulk Terminals, Inc., et al., Petitioners v.
International Longshoremen's Association, et al. Argued by Mr.
Thomas P. Gies for the petitioners and by Mr. Ernest L. Mathews, Jr.
for the respondents.
No. 80-1663. International Longshoremen's Association, AFL-CIO,
et al., Petitioners v. Allied International, Inc. Argued by Mr. Ernest L.
Mathews, Jr. for the petitioners, by Mr. Duane R. Batista for the re-
spondent, and by Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace for the United States as
amicus curiae, by special leave of Court.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

III
OPINIONS
No. 80-5727. Monty Lee Eddings, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. Judgment re-
versed to the extent that it sustains the imposition of the death penalty,
and case remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice Powell. Concurring opinion by Justice Brennan. Concurring opin-
ion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice with
whom Justice White, Justice Blackmun, and Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 80-847. Common Cause, et al., Appellants v. Harrison Schmitt,
et al.; and
No. 80-1067. Federal Election Commission, Appellant v. Americans
for Change, et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the
District of Columbia. Judgments affirmed by an equally divided Court.
Opinion per curiam. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration
or decision of these cases.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 80-1481. Bread Political Action Committee, et al., Appellants v.
Federal Election Commission, et al. Argued by Mr. Jeffrey Cole for the
appellants and by Mr. Charles N. Steele for the appellees.

364
TUESDAY, JANUARY 19, 1982
No. 80–1749. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, et al., Appel-
lants v. Mississippi, et al. Argued by Mr. Solicitor General Rex E. Lee
for the appellants and by Mr. Alex A. Alston, Jr. for the appellees.
No. 80–1199. American Tobacco Company, et al., Petitioners v. John
Patterson, et al. Argued by Mr. Henry T. Wickham for the petitioners
American Tobacco Co., et al., by Mr. Ronald Rosenberg for the peti-
tioner Unions, by Mr. Henry L. Marsh, III, for the respondents John
Patterson, et al., and by Mr. David A. Strauss for the respondent
EEOC, pro hac vice, by special leave of Court.
No. 80-1190. Pullman-Standard, A Division of Pullman, Incorpo-
rated, Petitioner v. Louis Swint and Willie Johnson, etc.; and
No. 80-1193. United Steelworkers of America, AFL-CIO, et al., Pe-
titioners v. Louis Swint and Willie James Johnson. Argued by Mr. Mi-
chael H. Gottesman for the petitioners and by Miss Elaine R. Jones for
the respondents.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1982
367
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Powell, Justice
Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
Justice Brennan said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by me, filed with the
Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-476. Walter W. Cohen, etc., et al., Appellants v. Disciplinary
Board of the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Middle District. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Jus-
tice White and Justice Stevens would postpone further consideration of
the question of jurisdiction to a hearing of the case on the merits.
No. 81–639. Lawrence Regira, Jr., et al., Appellants v. Ralph
Falsetta, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81-840. Gene Peters, Appellant v. Les J. Sjoholm, et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Washington. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 81-1002. Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company, Appellant v.
Office of Consumers' Counsel, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Ohio. The motion of Edison Electric Institute for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of a prop-
erly presented federal question.
No. 81-1031. David Treen, et al., Appellants v. Karen B., et al. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The
judgment is affirmed.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-6725. Andrew Phillip Legare, Petitioner v. Walter B. Zant,
Superintendent, Georgia Diagnostic & Classification Center. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Supreme Court of Georgia for further consideration in
light of Eddings v. Oklahoma, 455 U.S.
(1982).

368
MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1982
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Local 806, Allied Industrial Workers of America, AFL-
CIO, Petitioner v. Caterpillar Tractor Co. and National Labor Rela-
tions Board. The motion of petitioner to direct the Clerk to file the peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari is denied.
No. A-574. John C. Amis, President, Amey-Monge, Inc., Applicant
v. United States and Arthur Brake, Revenue Agent, IRS. The applica-
tion for stay addressed to Justice O'Connor and referred to the Court is
denied.
No. A-593. Janice Ching Yee, Applicant v. Harold Shintaku, Judge,
et al. The application for stay addressed to Justice O'Connor and re-
ferred to the Court is denied.
No. A-610. Local 1814, International Longshoremen's Association,
etc., et al., applicants v. Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.
The application for stay addressed to Justice Blackmun and referred to
the Court is denied.
No. 78–1545. Anne B. Zipes, et al., Petitioners v. Trans World Air-
lines, Inc.; and
No. 80–951. Independent Federation of Flight Attendants, Petitioner
v. Trans World Airlines, Inc., et al. The motion of petitioner in No. 80-
951 for leave to file a supplemental brief, after argument, is granted.
Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this mo-
tion.
No. 80–1429. Duane Youngberg, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Nicholas
Romeo, an Incompetent by his Mother and Next Friend, Paula Romeo.
The motion of Lowell P. Weicker, Jr., et al. to reconsider denial of
leave to file a brief as amici curiae, out of time, is denied.
No. 80-1924. Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Defense, et al.,
Petitioners v. Anthony M. Rossi, et al. The motion of William V. Chap-
pell, Jr., et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 81-55. New York, Petitioner v. Paul Ira Ferber. The motion of
Covenant House for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
The motion of Charles H. Keating, Jr., et al. for leave to file a brief as
amici curiae is granted.
No. 81–150. Northern Pipeline Construction Co., Appellant v. Mara-
thon Pipe Line Company and United States; and
No. 81-546. United States, Appellant v. Marathon Pipe Line Co., et
al. The motion of Commercial Law League of America for leave to par-
ticipate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for additional time for
oral argument is denied.

MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1982
369
No. 81-225. Blue Shield of Virginia, et al., Petitioners v. Carol
McCready. The motion of American Psychological Association for leave
to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 81-341. Joseph Greene, et al., Appellants v. Linnie Lindsey, et
al. The motion of National Housing Law Project for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 81-349. Chicago Bridge & Iron Company, Appellant v. Caterpil-
lar Tractor Co., et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to
participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument
is granted. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision
of this motion.
No. 81-411. Jackson Transit Authority, et al., Petitioners v. Local
Division 1285, Amalgamated Transit Union, AFL-CIO-CLC. The mo-
tion of Public Service Research Council for leave to file a brief as ami-
cus curiae is granted. The motion of National Institute of Municipal
Law Officers for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The
motion of American Public Transit Association for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted.
No. 81-420. R.C. Marshall, Superintendent, Southern Ohio Correc-
tional Facility, Petitioner v. Robert Lonberger. The motion for appoint-
ment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that John Czarnecki, Es-
quire, of Toledo, Ohio, is appointed to serve as counsel for the
respondent in this case.
No. 81-451. Ralph Hathorn, et al., Petitioners v. Mrs. Bobby
Lovorn, et al. The motion of the parties to dispense with printing the
joint appendix is denied.
No. 81-1112. Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, et al., Petitioners
v. Robert W. Johnson, et al. The motion of petitioners to expedite con-
sideration of the petition for certiorari is denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED OR POSTPONED
No. 81-708. City of Port Arthur, Texas, Appellant v. United States,
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit. The motion of appellees Jenkins and Douglas for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. In this case probable
jurisdiction is noted.
No. 81-750. Fidelity Federal Savings and Loan Association, et al.,
Appellants v. Reginald D. de la Cuesta, et al. Appeal from the Court of
Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate District. In this case probable
jurisdiction is noted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.

370
MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1982
No. 81–1282. National Organization for Women, Inc., et al., Appel-
lants v. Idaho, et al.; and
No. 81-1312. Gerald P. Carmen, Administrator, General Services,
Appellant v. Idaho, et al. Appeals from the United States District
Court for the District of Idaho. The motion of appellants in No. 81-1282
to expedite consideration of the jurisdictional statement is granted. The
motion, in all other respects including the request to expedite plenary
consideration, is denied. The motion of Democratic National Committee
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae in No. 81-1282 is granted. The
motion of American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial
Organizations, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae in Nos. 81-
1282 and 81-1283 is granted. The motion of Thomas P. O'Neill, Jr., et al.
for leave to file a brief as amici curiae in Nos. 81-1282 and 81-1283 is
granted. The motion of Jake Garn, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici
curiae in Nos. 81-1282 and 81-1283 is granted. The motion of Joseph E.
Brennan, Governor of Maine, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici cu-
riae in Nos. 81-1282 and 81-1283 is granted. The motion of Charles
Robb, Governor of Virginia, et al. for leave to join the motion of Joseph
E. Brennan, Governor of Maine, et al. in Nos. 81-1282 and 81-1283 is
granted. The motion of American Bar Association for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motions of ERAmerica, et al. for
leave to file briefs as amici curiae in Nos. 80-1282 and 81-1283 are
granted. In these cases further consideration of the question of jurisdic-
tion is postponed to the hearing of the cases on the merits. The cases
are consolidated with Nos. 81-1283 and 81-1313. The judgment of the
United States District Court for the District of Idaho is stayed pending
the sending down of the judgment of this Court.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 81-1003. Kevin H. White, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Massachu-
setts Council of Construction Employers, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts granted.
No. 81-1283. National Organization for Women, et al., Petitioners, v.
Idaho, et al.; and
No. 81-1313. Gerald P. Carmen, Administrator, General Services,
Petitioner, v. Idaho, et al. The motion of petitioners in No. 81-1283 to
expedite consideration of the petition for a writ of certiorari before
judgment is granted. The motion, in all other respects including the re-
quest to expedite plenary consideration, is denied. The petitions for
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit before judgment are granted. The cases are consolidated with
Nos. 81-1282 and 81-1312. The judgment of the United States District
Court for the District of Idaho is stayed pending the sending down of
the judgment of this Court.

No. 80-1082. Harold J. Smith, Superintendent, Attica Correctional
Facility, Petitioner v. William R. Phillips. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan and Justice
Stevens join.
No. 80–1431. In the Matter of R----M.J----, Appellant. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Missouri. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Supreme Court of Missouri for further proceedings not incon-
sistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Powell.
No. 80-11. J. Gregory Merrion and Robert L. Bayless, etc., et al.,
Petitioners v. Jicarilla Apache Tribe, et al.; and
No. 80-15. Amoco Production Company and Marathon Oil Company,
Petitioners v. Jicarilla Apache Tribe, et al. On writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Rehnquist join.
☑
Adjourned until Monday, February 22, 1982 at 10 o'clock.

FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1982
385
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
-
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No.
Robert C. Haldeman, Trustee of Lehigh Valley Railroad
Company, Appellant v. United States Railway Association, et al. The
appeal is dismissed without prejudice it appearing that the appeal
would not be in the interest of an expeditious conclusion to the
proceedings.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1982
387
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
PER CURIAM
No. 81-96. James H. Tully, Jr., et al., Appellants v. Mobil Oil Cor-
poration, et al. Appeal from the United States Temporary Emergency
Court of Appeals. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States Temporary Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light of the
expiration of federal price control authority under the EPAA. Opinion
per curiam. Justice Brennan would set the case for oral argument. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Stevens.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-1028. Anna Williams, Appellant v. William Williams. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of New Hampshire. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81-1048. Peter S. Razatos, Appellant v. Colorado. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Colorado. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 81-1104. S. H. Goss, Inc., et al., Appellants v. Pennsylvania De-
partment of Agriculture. Appeal from the Commonwealth Court of
Pennsylvania. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 81–1164. John Franklin Hein, Appellant v. California. Appeal
from the Appellate Department of Superior Court of California, County
of San Diego. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 81-5943. Charles H. Bixby, Appellant v. Philip Ross, etc. Appeal
from the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York, Third Judi-
cial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question.
No. 81-6012. Richard A. Cepulonis, Appellant v. Massachusetts. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.

388
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1982
No. 81-1041. Stan Musial & Biggies, Inc., Appellant v. Florida, De-
partment of Revenue. Appeal from the District Court of Appeal of
Florida, First District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 81–1183. Southern State College, et al., Appellants v. Arkansas
Gazette Company. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Arkansas. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 81-5967. Monty E. Robinson, etc., Appellant v. R. Armand, et
al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-723. Hybud Equipment Corp., et al., Petitioners v. City of
Akron, Ohio, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Community Communications Co., Inc. v. City
of Boulder, Colorado, 455 U.S. (1982).
-
No. 81-843. Northwest Excavating, Inc., Petitioner v. William C.
Waggoner, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certio-
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Kaiser Steel Corp. v. Mullins, 455 U.S. —
(1982).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. In the Matter of Admission of Leda M. C. Hartwell. The
application for admission is granted. Dissenting opinion by Chief Jus-
tice Burger.
No. 80 Original. State of Colorado, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico
and Jeff Bingaman, Attorney General of the State of New Mexico. The
Report of the Special Master on the Equitable Apportionment of the
Vermejo River is received and ordered filed. Exceptions, if any, with
supporting briefs to the Report may be filed by the parties within 45
days. Reply briefs, if any, to such Exceptions may be filed within 30
days.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1982
389
No. 85 Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of Oklahoma. The
Report of the Special Master on motion for entry of judgment is re-
ceived and ordered filed. Exceptions, if any, with supporting briefs to
the Report may be filed by the parties within 30 days. Reply briefs, if
any, to such Exceptions may be filed within 15 days.
No. 78–1545. Anne B. Zipes, et al., Petitioners v. Trans World Air-
lines, Inc.; and
No. 80-951. Independent Federation of Flight Attendants, Petitioner
v. Trans World Airlines, Inc., et al. The motion of respondent Trans
World Airlines, Inc. for leave to file a supplemental brief after argu-
ment is granted. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.
No. 80-644. G. D. Searle & Company, Petitioner v. Susan Cohn and
Walter Cohn. The motion of respondents for leave to file a supplemen-
tal brief after argument is granted.

School District, Westchester County, et al., Petitioners v. Amy Row-
ley, by her Parents and Natural Guardians, Clifford and Nancy Row-
ley, etc. The motion of respondents to permit interpretation of oral ar-
gument is granted. The motion of The Solicitor General for leave to
participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument
is granted.
No. 80-1012. Baxter Rice, Director, Department of Alcoholic Bever-
age Control of California, Petitioner v. Norman Williams Company, et
al.;
No. 80-1030. Bohemian Distributing Company, Petitioner v. Norman
Williams Company, et al.; and

Distributing Company and Wine & Spirits Wholesalers of California for
divided argument is granted. The motion of petitioner Baxter Rice, Di-
rector, etc., for divided argument is granted.

sources. The motion of the Attorney General of New York for leave to
participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for additional time
for oral argument is denied.

is denied. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall would grant the peti-

White would grant certiorari to resolve the conflict between the deci-

of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit in Argonaut Insurance Co. v. Na-
tional Indemnity Co., 435 F.2d 718 and Hagans v. Glens Falls Insur-

OPINIONS
No. 80-1577. City of Mesquite, Appellant v. Aladdin's Castle, Inc.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment reversed in part and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by Justice White concurring in
part and dissenting in part. Opinion by Justice Powell concurring in
part and dissenting in part.
No. 80-1614. George F. Jewett, Jr., et ux., Petitioners v. Commis-
sioner of Internal Revenue. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom
Justice Rehnquist and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 80–60. Elvina M. Herweg, by her husband and next friend, Dar-
rell E. Herweg and Darrell E. Herweg, etc., Petitioners v. Robert D.
Ray, Governor of Iowa, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States.
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Opinion
by Justice Stevens concurring in part. Dissenting opinion by Chief Jus-
tice Burger.
No. 80–767. United States, Appellant v. Edwin D. Lee. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Western District of Pennsyl-
vania. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the District Court for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Chief Justice Burger. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in
the judgment.

432
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1982
No. 79-1618. Consolidated Freightways Corporation of Delaware,
Petitioner v. Raymond Kassel, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The writ of certiorari is
dismissed as improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting
opinion by Justice White. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this case.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 80–1990. Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Defense, et al.,

respondents.

OPINIONS
.
No. 80–644. G. D. Searle & Company, Petitioner v. Susan Cohn and
Walter Cohn. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Third Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Opinion by Justice Powell
concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom the Chief Justice
joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 80-5950. Laverne L. Logan, Appellant v. Zimmerman Brush
Company, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Illinois for fur-
ther proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Blackmun. Separate opinion by Justice Blackmun, with
whom Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice O'Connor join.
Opinion by Justice Powell concurring in the judgment with whom Jus-
tice. Rehnquist joins.
No. 78–1545. Anne B. Zipes, et al., Petitioners v. Trans World Air-
lines, Inc.;
No. 78–1549. Trans World Airlines, Inc., Petitioner v. Anne B.
Zipes, et al.; and
No. 80-951. Independent Federation of Flight Attendants, Petitioner
v. Trans World Airlines, Inc., et al. On writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment in No.
78-1545 is reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Judg-
ment in No. 80-951 is affirmed. In No. 78–1549, the writ is dismissed as
improvidently granted. Opinion by Justice White. Opinion by Justice
Powell concurring in No. 78-1545 and concurring in the judgment in
No. 80-951 with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Rehnquist join.
Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of these
cases.

434
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1982
No. 80-988. Havens Realty Corporation, et al., Petitioners v. Sylvia
Coleman, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in
part and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Bren-
nan. Concurring opinion by Justice Powell.
No. 80-1208. New England Power Company, Appellant v. New
Hampshire, et al.;
No. 80-1471. Massachusetts, et al., Appellants v. New Hampshire, et
al.; and

Rhode Island, et al., Appellants v. New Hampshire, et al. Appeals from
the Supreme Court of New Hampshire. Judgment reversed and cases
remanded to the Supreme Court of New Hampshire for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Chief Justice Burger.
No. 80-1436. Malcolm Baldrige, Secretary of Commerce, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Peter Shapiro, Essex County Executive. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit; and
No. 80-1781. William H. McNichols, Jr., etc., et al., Petitioners v.
Malcolm Baldrige, Secretary of the United States Department of Com-
merce, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit. In No. 80-1436, judgment is reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. In No. 80-1781, judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Chief Justice Burger.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 1, 1982
437
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80–629. Maren Engineering Corp., Appellant v. Konstantin
Velmohos. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of New
Jersey for further consideration in light of G. D. Searle and Company
v. Cohn, 455 U.S. (1982). Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens and
Justice O'Connor would dismiss the appeal for want of jurisdiction.
-
No. 81-960. Ronald C. Locke and Leslie L. Flage, Appellants v.
Florida. Appeal from the District Court of Appeal of Florida, First Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81-1035. Patricia Laird, etc. and Shelton Fletcher Horne, Appel-
lants v. South Carolina. Appeal from the Supreme Court of South Caro-
lina. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the pa-
pers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 81-1161. Neil H. Hightower, etc., et al., Appellants v. George
Searcy, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit. The judgment is affirmed.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80–663. Kelsey-Hayes, Inc., Petitioner v. Roy Hopkins. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Cir-
cuit. The petition for certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit for further consideration in light of G. D. Searle and
Company v. Cohn, 455 U.S. (1982).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-672. Alan Ernest, etc., Applicant v. Richard S. Cohen, etc., et
al. Application for an injunction addressed to Justice O'Connor and re-
ferred to the Court is denied.

438
MONDAY, MARCH 1, 1982
No. 80-1121. United States, Petitioner v. Joseph J. Clark, et al. The
motion of respondents not to tax costs is denied.
No. 80-1305. Alfred L. Snapp & Son, Inc., et al., Petitioners v.
Puerto Rico, ex rel. Pedro Barez, Secretary of Labor and Human Re-
sources. The motion of Migrant Legal Action Program, Inc., et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 80-2100. Quentin Rogers, et al., Appellants v. Herman Lodge, et
al. The motion of appellants for leave to file a delayed reply brief is
granted.
No. 80-2146. Florida, Petitioner v. Mark Royer. The motion of the
Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus cu-
riae, for divided argument and for additional time for oral argument is
granted and five additional minutes are allotted for that purpose. The
respondent is also allotted an additional five minutes for oral argument.
No. 81–184. United States, Appellant v. Security Industrial Bank, et
al. The motion of the Solicitor General to dispense with printing the
joint appendix is granted.
No. 81–334. Associated General Contractors of California, Inc., Peti-
tioner v. California State Council of Carpenters; and Carpenters 46
Northern Counties Conference Board, et al. The motion of the Solicitor
General to dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 81-411. Jackson Transit Authority, et al., Petitioners v. Local Di-
vision 1285, Amalgamated Transit Union, AFL-CIO-CLC. The motion
of Railway Labor Executives' Association for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted.
No. 81-430. Illinois, Petitioner v. Lance Gates, et ux. The motion of
petitioner for leave to amend or enlarge question presented for review
is denied.
No. 81-485. Hillsboro National Bank, Petitioner v. Commissioner of
Internal Revenue. The motion of the Solicitor General to dispense with
printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 81-525. Charles V. Bowen, Petitioner v. United States Postal
Service, et al. The motion of The Solicitor General for divided argument
is granted. The request for additional time for oral argument is denied.
No. 81-876. St. Luke's Federation of Nurses and Health Profes-
sionals, Petitioner v. Presbyterian/St. Luke's Medical Center; Beth Is-
rael Federation of Nurses and Health Professionals, etc., Petitioner v.
Beth Israel Hospital; and Geriatric Center and St. Anthony's Federa-
tion of Nurses and Health Professionals, etc., Petitioner v. St. Anthony
Hospital Systems. The motion of petitioners to defer consideration of
the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted.

439
No. 81–912. James Click, Sr., Eugene Weiss and Orral Lake, Peti-
tioners v. Idaho, ex rel. John V. Evans, Governor, et al. The Solicitor

United States.
No. 81-930. United States, Petitioner v. Bliss Dairy, Inc. The motion
of the Solicitor General to dispense with printing the joint appendix is
granted.
No. 81-1020. Exxon Corporation, et al., Appellants v. Ralph
Eagerton, Jr., Commissioner of Revenue of Alabama, et al.; and
No. 81-1268. Exchange Oil and Gas Corporation, et al., Appellants v.

pressing the views of the United States.

probable jurisdiction is noted.
No. 81–802. City of Lockhart, Appellant v. United States and Alfred

Columbia. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.

OPINIONS
No. 80-415. Railway Labor Executives' Association, Appellant v.
William M. Gibbons, Trustee, et al. On appeal from the United States
District Court for the Northern District of Illinois; and
No. 80-1239. Railway Labor Executives' Association, Appellant v.
William M. Gibbons, Trustee, et al. On appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment in No. 80-415 is
vacated and case remanded to the District Court with instructions to
dismiss the complaint as moot. See United States v. Munsingwear,
Inc., 340 U.S. 36, 39 (1950). Judgment in No. 80-1239 is affirmed. Opin-
ion by Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Justice Marshall concurring in the
judgment with whom Justice Brennan joins.
No. 80-5887. Richard H. White, Petitioner v. New Hampshire De-
partment of Employment Security, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Powell. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in the Judgment.
No. 80-2165. James M. Murphy, District Judge, Fourth Judicial Dis-
trict of the State of Nebraska, Douglas County, Appellant v. Eugene L.
Hunt. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
with instructions that the complaint be dismissed. Opinion per curiam.
Dissenting opinion by Justice White.

OPINIONS
No. 80-846. Jim Rose, Warden, Petitioner v. Noah Harrison Lundy.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the judgment of this Court.
Justice O'Connor announced the Court's judgment and delivered an
opinion of the Court with respect to Parts I, II, III-A, III-B and IV, in
which Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice
Powell and Justice Rehnquist joined, and an opinion with respect to
Part III-C, in which Chief Justice Burger, Justice Powell and Justice
Rehnquist joined. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in the judg-
ment. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in part and dissenting in
part with whom Justice Marshall join. Opinion by Justice White concur-
ring in part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens.
No. 80-1681. Village of Hoffman Estates, et al., Appellants v.
Flipside, Hoffman Estates, Inc. Appeal from the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Opinion by
Justice White concurring in the judgment. Justice Stevens took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.

456
WEDNESDAY, MARCH 3, 1982
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 80-1798. Woelke & Romero Framing, Inc., Petitioner v. Na-
tional Labor Relations Board, et al.;

Contractors, Inc., Petitioner v. National Labor Relations Board, et al.;
and
No. 81–91. Oregon-Columbia Chapter, The Associated General Con-
tractors of America, Inc., Petitioner v. National Labor Relations
Board, et al. One hour and twenty minutes allowed for oral argument.

for the respondent unions.

United Contractors Association, Petitioners v. Pennsylvania, et al.;
No. 81-332. Glasgow, Inc., Petitioner v. Pennsylvania, et al.; and
No. 81-333. Bechtel Power Corporation, Petitioner v. Pennsylvania,
et al. One hour and thirty minutes allowed for oral argument. Argued
by Mr. John J. McAleese, Jr., for the petitioners in 81-330, et al., by
Mr. John G. Kester for the petitioners in 81-280, et al., and by Mr.
Harold I. Goodman for the respondents.
Adjourned until Monday, March 8, 1982 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 8, 1982
457
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, and
Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-2003. Honda Motor Company, Ltd., Appellant v. Walter P.
Coons. Appeal from the Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Divi-
sion. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Superior
Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division, for further consideration in
light of G. D. Searle and Company v. Cohn, 455 U.S. (1982). Jus-
tice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor would dismiss the
appeal for want of jurisdiction.
No. 81-865. Metrocentre Improvement District No. 1, City of Little
Rock, Arkansas, Appellant v. Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
The judgment is affirmed. Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist and
Justice O'Connor would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for
oral argument.
No. 81-1315. Robert Westphalen, Appellant v. City of Chicago, et al.
Appeal from the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 81-6055. Olga Hernandez, Appellant v. Department of Labor and
Human Resources, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Puerto
Rico. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the pa-
pers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 81-1324. Meade H. Esposito, Appellant v. Robert Abrams, At-
torney General of the State of New York. Appeal from the Court of Ap-
peals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-1038. Jack Duckworth, Warden, et al., Petitioners v. William
L. Cowell. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is

458
MONDAY, MARCH 8, 1982
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit with directions
that it instruct the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of Indiana to dismiss the petition for a writ of habeas corpus. Rose
v. Lundy, 55 U.S. (1982). Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens
would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari.
No. 81-1098. Central Intelligence Agency and William J. Casey, Pe-
titioners v. Holy Spirit Association for the Unification of World Chris-
tianity. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Petition for writ of certio-
rari granted. Upon the representation of counsel for respondent set
forth in her letter of February 18, 1982 and the response of the Solicitor
General filed February 24, 1982, the judgment is vacated insofar as it
affirms the decision of the United States District Court for the District
of Columbia requiring the disclosure of the six documents in question
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit with directions that it instruct the United
States District Court to dismiss this aspect of the case as moot.
No. 81-5047. Marcelo Rodriquez, Petitioner v. David R. Harris, Su-
perintendent, Green Haven Correctional Facility. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Cir-
cuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is va-
cated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit with directions that it instruct the United States
District Court for the Southern District of New York to dismiss the pe-
tition for a writ of habeas corpus. Rose v. Lundy, 455 U.S. (1982).
Justice Stevens would grant the petition for a writ of certiorari and set
the case for oral argument.

nor joins.

No. 89 Original. State of California, ex rel. State Lands Commission,

to file a supplemental brief is granted.

ferred to the Court is denied.

v. Arkansas Public Service Commission. The Solicitor General is in-
vited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States.
No. 81-1055. David B. Poythress, et al., Petitioners v. Elizabeth B.
Duncan, et al. The motion of respondents to advance case for oral argu-
ment and for abridgement of time to file briefs is denied.
No. 81–1114. Illinois, Petitioner v. Abbott & Associates, Inc., et al.
The application of "undisclosed respondents" for an order to keep identi-
ties of certain respondents held in camera presented to Justice Stevens
and by him referred to the Court is granted.
No. 81–1565. VSL Corporation, Petitioner v. United States. The mo-
tion of petitioner for an order placing the petition for a writ of certio-
rari, brief in opposition and record under seal is denied.
No. 81-1589. Hugh S. Hunt, Petitioner v. Jerry L. Collins. The appli-
cation for stay addressed to Justice Brennan and referred to the Court
is denied.

Circuit. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.

World Industries, Inc., et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is

brief as amicus curiae is granted. The petitions for writs of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit
are denied. Justice White, Justice Blackmun and Justice Powell would
grant certiorari. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or
decision of these petitions and motions.

No. 80-1481. Bread Political Action Committee, et al., Appellants v.

Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity

of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens.

for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 22, 1982
475
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 81-362. Louie L. Wainwright, Secretary, Florida Department of
Corrections, Petitioner v. Jose Torna. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for cer-
tiorari granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam. Justice Brennan would set the case for oral
argument. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 81–844. George Sumner, Warden, Petitioner v. Robert Mata. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and
casę remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 81-1049. Lloyd Fletcher, Superintendent, Bell County Forestry
Camp, Petitioner v. Eric Weir. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Motion of re-
spondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for certio-
rari granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam. Justice Brennan would set the case for oral
argument. Justice Marshall dissents from the summary reversal of this
case.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-1356. Clifford Jones, Appellant v. William M. Morris, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern District
of Ohio. The judgment is affirmed.

476
MONDAY, MARCH 22, 1982
No. 81-5827. In Re Norma Turner, Appellant. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction.
No. 81-6073. Danny Angelo Fluker, Appellant v. Georgia. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction.
No. 81-6097. James E. Richards, Appellant v. City of Los Angeles.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81-6106. Richard C. Ivey, Petitioner v. Alaska. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Alaska. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 81-6157. Manfred Wolfson, Appellant v. Paul Murray, et al. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 76–1234. Samuel R. Pierce, Jr., Secretary of Housing and Urban
Development, et al., Petitioners v. Barbara Ross, et al. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit;
and
No. 76–1261. Samuel R. Pierce, Jr., Secretary of Housing and Urban
Development, et al., Petitioners v. Hilda Abrams, et al. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Upon consideration of the motion to vacate filed by the Solicitor Gen-
eral on March 11, 1982, the judgments of the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit and the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit are vacated and the cases are remanded to the
United States District Court for the District of Maryland and the
United States District Court for the Central District of California, re-
spectively, with directions to dismiss the causes as moot when the par-
ties jointly so move.

ordered that Martin E. Gotkin, of New York, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

ordered that Stanley Roy Root, of New York, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

ordered that Bernard J. Coven, of New York, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

in No. 81-1371 is granted. The motion of National Congress of Ameri-
can Indians, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.

Claims denied.
No. 81-1406. Alan I. Greene, Petitioner v. Grievance Committee for
the Ninth Judicial District. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of
Appeals of New York denied. Justice Brennan, Justice White, Justice
Blackmun and Justice Powell would grant the petition, vacate the judg-
ment and remand the case to the Court of Appeals of New York for fur-
ther consideration in light of In the Matter of R-M.J, 455 U.S.
(1982).

verse the conviction.
