OPINIONS
No. 80-6680. Charles Ronald McElroy, Petitioner v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 80-518. U.S. Industries/Federal Sheet Metal, Inc., et al., Peti-
tioners v. Director, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs, United
States Department of Labor, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice
Marshall joins. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of this case.

504
TUESDAY, MARCH 23, 1982
No. 80-1240. Michael P. Lane, Director, Illinois Department of Cor-
rections, Petitioner v. Lawrence Williams and Oscar Southall. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with
whom Justice Brennan and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 80-1690. American Medical Association, et al., Petitioners v.
Federal Trade Commission. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed by an
equally divided Court. Opinion per curiam, announced by the Chief
Justice. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision
of this case.

respondent.

respondent.

OPINIONS
No. 80-702. United States, Petitioner v. New Mexico, et al. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
No. 80-5889. John Santosky, II and Annie Santosky, Petitioners v.
Bernhardt S. Kramer, Commissioner, Ulster County Department of
Social Services, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Appellate Division,
Supreme Court of New York, Third Judicial Department. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Appellate Division for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom
Chief Justice Burger, Justice White and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 80–1496. Underwriters National Assurance Company, Petitioner
v. North Carolina Life and Accident and Health Insurance Guaranty
Association, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of North
Carolina. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceeding not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Opinion by Justice White concur-
ring in the judgment with whom Justice Powell and Justice Stevens
join.
No. 80–1925. United Transportation Union, Petitioner v. Long Is-
land Railroad Company, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceeding in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Chief Justice Burger.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 29, 1982
507
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-1000. California State Board of Equalization, Appellant v.
United States. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The judgment is affirmed.
No. 81-1505. Camellia Corporation, Appellant v. Deborah Cornell.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-755. Bobby E. Yates, Applicant v. United States Coast Guard
and United States. The application for an injunction addressed to Jus-
tice O'Connor and referred to the Court is denied.
No. A-783. Alan J. Karcher, Speaker, New Jersey Assembly, et al.,
Applicants v. George T. Daggett, et al. The motions of appellees to va-
cate the stay entered by Justice Brennan on March 15, 1982, and the
requests to expedite docketing of the appeal are denied.
No. A-786. Louis Terrazas, et al., Applicants v. William P.
Clements, Governor of Texas, et al. The application for stay of the or-
der of the United States District Court for the Northern District of
Texas presented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court is
denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this application.
No. A-791. Donnie Jay Carpenter, Applicant v. Ross Jamerson,
Sheriff. The application to continue the stay entered by the Supreme
Court of Ohio addressed to Justice Brennan and referred to the Court is
denied.
No. A-826. Queensgate Investment Company, dba Holiday Inn, Ap-
plicant v. Liquor Control Commission of Ohio. The application for stay
presented to Justice O'Connor and by her referred to the Court is
denied.

MONDAY, MARCH 29, 1982
No. D-248. In the Matter of Disbarment of Dennis Holober. Disbar-
ment entered.
No. D-249. In the Matter of Disbarment of Elmer S. Beatty, Jr. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-255. In the Matter of Disbarment of James R. Holman. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-261. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert K. Hammersmith.
It is ordered that Robert K. Hammersmith, of Columbus, Ohio, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-262. In the Matter of Disbarment of John F. Auwaerter. It is
ordered that John F. Auwaerter, of Sylvania, Ohio, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D–263. In the Matter of Disbarment of John W. Kitchen. It is
ordered that John W. Kitchen, of Toledo, Ohio, be suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-264. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joshua Eilberg. It is or-
dered that Joshua Eilberg, of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 80-1952. Barbara Blum, Commissioner of the New York State
Department of Social Services, et al., Petitioners v. William Yaretsky,
et al. The motion of petitioners for leave to file reply brief out of time is
granted.
No. 81–184. United States, Appellant v. Security Industrial Bank, et
al. The motion of Security Industrial Bank for divided argument and for
additional time for oral argument is denied.
No. 81-334. Associated General Contractors of California, Inc., Peti-
tioner v. California State Council of Carpenters and Carpenters 46
Northern Counties Conference Board, et al. The motion of respondent
for divided argument to permit American Federation of Labor and Con-
gress of Industrial Organizations to present oral argument as amicus
curiae is denied.

509
No. 81-395. United Steelworkers of America, AFL-CIO-CLC, Peti-

of American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organiza-

denied.

spondent to strike portions of petitioner's reply brief is denied.

Power and Light Company. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Kansas.
The motion of State Corporation Commission of Kansas for leave to file
a brief as amicus curiae is granted. In this case probable jurisdiction is
noted.

by Justice Rehnquist.

for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.

in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom
Justice Brennan and Justice Blackmun join.

MONDAY, APRIL 5, 1982
527
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Justice Brennan, Justice White, Justice Marshall, Justice
Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, and Jus-
tice O'Connor.
Justice Brennan said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by me, filed with the
Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-5227. Cheryl Maffey, Appellant v. Oregon ex rel. Juvenile
Department of Klamath County. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
Oregon. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 81-1034. Richard Rock, Appellant v. Harry E. Stowers, Jr., Dis-
trict Judge, Bernalillo County. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New
Mexico. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
ORDERS IN Pending CaSES
No. A-818. Michael J. Conway, Applicant v. United States. The
application for stay addressed to Justice Marshall and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. A-829. Division 732, Amalgamated Transit Union, Applicant v.
Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority. The application for stay
presented to Justice Powell and by him referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-250. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert C. Donovan. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-254. In the Matter of Disbarment of Walter Carl Wencke. Dis-
barment entered.
No. 8 Original. State of Arizona, Plaintiff v. State of California, et
al. The Report of the Special Master is received and ordered filed. Ex-
ceptions, if any, with supporting briefs to the Report may be filed by
the parties within 45 days. Reply briefs, if any, to such Exceptions may
be filed within 30 days. Justice Marshall and Justice O'Connor took no
part in the consideration or decision of this order.

528
MONDAY, APRIL 5, 1982
No. 92 Original. State of Arkansas, Plaintiff v. State of Mississippi.
The motion for leave to file a bill of complaint is granted. The defendant
is allowed 60 days within which to answer.
No. 80-2070. Sumitomo Shoji America, Inc., Petitioner v. Lisa M.
Avigliano, et al.; and
No. 81-24. Lisa M. Avigliano, et al., Petitioners v. Sumitomo Shoji
America, Inc. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to partici-
pate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is
granted.
No. 81-298. Community Television of Southern California, Petitioner
v. Sue Gottfried, et al.; and
No. 81-799. Federal Communications Commission, Petitioner v. Sue
Gottfried, et al. The motion of respondents to apportion advancement of
funds for the printing of the joint appendix is denied.
No. 81-878. John P. Larkin, et al., Appellants v. Grendel's Den, Inc.
The motion of Paul W. Johnson, Esquire, to permit Gerald J. Caruso,
Esquire, to present oral argument pro hac vice is granted.
No. 81-920. Verlinden B. V., Petitioner v. Central Bank of Nigeria.
The motion of The Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argu-
ment as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted. The re-
quest for additional time for oral argument is denied.
No. 81-1404. Carlisle W. Briscoe, Chris P. Vickers, Sr., and James
N. Ballard, Petitioners v. Martin Lahue and James W. Hunley, etc.
The motion of petitioner Carlisle W. Briscoe for leave to proceed fur-
ther herein in forma pauperis is granted.
No. 81-1719. William O. Petrusch, Jr., etc., Petitioner v. Teamsters
Local 317, Syracuse, New York, et al. The application for an injunction
addressed to Justice Rehnquist and referred to the Court is denied.
No. 81-1770. Laverne Orwoll, et al., Appellants v. Sharon LaComb,
et al. The motion of Minnesota State Senate for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, is granted. The motion of appellants to expedite consid-
eration of the appeal is denied. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of these motions.

OPINIONS
No. 80-1430. Ted Engle, Superintendent, Chillicothe Correctional
Institute, Petitioner v. Lincoln Isaac; E. P. Perini, Superintendent,
Marion Correctional Institution, Petitioner v. Kenneth L. Bell; and Ted
Engle, Superintendent, Chillicothe Correctional Institute, Petitioner v.
Howard Hughes. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgments reversed and cases remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice
Stevens concurring in part and dissenting in part. Statement by Justice
Blackmun concurring in the result. Dissenting opinion by Justice Bren-
nan with whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 80-1595. United States, Petitioner v. Joseph C. Frady. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice Ste-
vens. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Brennan. The Chief Justice and Justice Mar-
shall took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 80-6298. Lois Mae Mills, Appellant v. Dan Habluetzel. Appeal
from the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Thirteenth Supreme Judicial
District. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Civil
Appeals of Texas for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by
Justice O'Connor with whom Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan and
Justice Blackmun join and in Part I of which Justice Powell joins. Opin-
ion by Justice Powell concurring in the judgment.
No. 80–1199. American Tobacco Company, et al., Petitioners v. John
Patterson, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun
join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.

MONDAY, APRIL 5, 1982
539
No. 80-1285. Carl W. Brown, Petitioner v. Earl J. Hartlage. On writ
of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Kentucky. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan.
Opinion by Justice Rehnquist concurring in the result. Statement by
Chief Justice Burger concurring in the judgment.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 19, 1982
543
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-1594. Robert V. Rafter, Appellant v. Elizabeth R. Higgins
and George B. Fargis. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 81-1621. Howard Matthew Bilford, et al., Appellants v. Florida.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction.
No. 81-1642. Best Investment Co., Appellant v. City of Dallas, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern District
of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-5861. Kenneth Ray Williams, Petitioner v. Kenneth Ray
Lucky. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of
Texas, Fifth Supreme Judicial District. The motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certio-
rari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the Court of Appeals of Texas, Fifth Supreme Judicial District, for fur-
ther consideration in light of Mills v. Habluetzel, 456 U.S. — (1982).
-
No. 80-6701. Daniel Ross, Petitioner v. Amos Reed, etc., et al. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in
light of Engle v. Isaac, 456 U.S. - (1982) and United States v.
Frady, 456 U.S. (1982).

544
MONDAY, APRIL 19, 1982
No. 81-1056. Washington, Petitioner v. George E. Myers. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Engle v. Isaac, 456 U.S. (1982) and United States v. Frady, 456
U.S.
(1982).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 80-2162. Ramah Navajo School Board, Inc., et al., Appellants v.
Bureau of Revenue of New Mexico. The motion of the Solicitor General
for leave to file a supplemental brief as amicus curiae is denied.
No. 81-451. Ralph Hathorn, et al., Petitioners v. Mrs. Bobby
Lovorn, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to file a sup-
plemental brief as amicus curiae is denied.
No. 81-1. Goldsboro Christian Schools, Inc., Petitioner v. United
States; and
No. 81-3. Bob Jones University, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of National Association for the Advancement of Colored People,
et al. for leave to intervene as parties respondent and for leave to par-
ticipate in oral argument is denied. The alternative request to file a
brief as amici curiae is granted. The motion of Laurence H. Tribe and
Bernard Wolfman for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
The motion of Agencies of the United Church of Christ for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Lawyers' Committee.
for Civil Rights Under Law, et al. for leave to file a supplemental brief
as amici curiae is granted. The motion of North Carolina Association of
Black Lawyers for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The
motion of the Solicitor General for leave to file a brief on the merits out-
of-time is granted. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to file a
motion for divided argument out-of-time is granted. The motion of peti-
tioner in No. 81–3 for an order directing respondent to act with respect
to respondent's memorandum filed January 8, 1982 is denied. The mo-
tions of petitioners for summary reversal are denied. William T. Cole-
man, Jr., Esquire, of Washington, D.C., a member of the Bar of this
Court, is invited to brief and argue these cases, as amicus curiae, in
support of the judgments below.
No. 81-184. United States, Appellant v. Security Industrial Bank, et

MONDAY, APRIL 19, 1982
545
al. The motion of appellee Beneficial Finance of Kansas, Inc. to sched-
ule oral argument during April, 1982 session is denied.
No. 81–298. Community Television of Southern California, Petitioner
v. Sue Gottfried, et al.; and
No. 81-799. Federal Communications Commission, Petitioner v. Sue
Gottfried, et al. The motions of petitioners for divided argument and for
additional time for oral argument are granted. Ten additional minutes
are allotted for that purpose.
No. 81-300. Ford Motor Company, Petitioner v. Equal Employment
Opportunity Commission. The motion of the Solicitor General to permit
David A. Strauss, Esquire, to present oral argument pro hac vice is
granted.
No. 81-750. Fidelity Federal Savings and Loan Association, et al.,
Appellants v. Reginald D. de la Cuesta, et al. The motion of Michigan,
et al. for leave to participate in oral argument as amici curiae and for
divided argument is denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this motion.
No. 81-825. The Pillsbury Company, et al., Petitioners v. John
Conboy. The motion of petitioners to schedule oral argument during
April, 1982 session is denied. The motion of Philip L. Barnum, et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Justice O'Connor took no
part in the consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 81-1180. G.R. Dickerson, Director, Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco
and Firearms, Petitioner v. New Banner Institute, Inc. The motion of
the parties to dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 81-1476. United States, Petitioner v. Lucille Mitzi Bosco Rodg-
ers, et al.; and United States, Petitioner v. Joerene Ingram, et al. The
motion of the parties to dispense with printing the joint appendix is
granted.
No. 81-1591. The Chase Manhattan Bank, N.A., Petitioner v.
Vishipco Line, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 81–1860. J. P. Stevens & Co., Inc., Petitioner v. National Labor
Relations Board, et al. The motion of petitioner to expedite consider-
ation of the petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.

No. 81-6353. Herbert Russell Bassett, Petitioner v. Virginia. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Virginia denied. Dis-
senting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 81-6112. Robert H. Fendler, Petitioner v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this petition.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 81-6277. In Re Richard Francis De Vincent, Petitioner; and
No. 81-6342. In Re Clovis Carl Green, Jr., Petitioner. Petitions for
writs of mandamus denied.
No. 81-1483. In Re Westley Williams, et al., Petitioners. The motion
of FLAG, Inc. for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Peti-
tion for writ of mandamus denied.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, APRIL 23, 1982
575
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Powell, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-889. Jeff Bingaman, et al., Applicants v. Bruce King, etc., et
al. It is ordered that the order of the United States District Court for
the District of New Mexico, in consolidated cases Nos. 82-67-M,
82-84-C, 82-180-C, 82-219-JB, and 82-246-JB, entered on April 13,
1982, be, and the same is hereby, stayed to the extent that that order
applies to primary elections other than for state legislative offices,
pending the timely filing and disposition by this Court of an appeal.
This order shall have no effect on the orders of the United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of New Mexico in the cases set forth above
entered on April 5 and April 8, 1982, enjoining the primary filing dead-
line for New Mexico state legislative election and adjudging the New
Mexico apportionment plan unconstitutional.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1982
577
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-1310. Anthony Ragno, Appellant v. Florida. Appeal from the
District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction.
Rexford
No. 81-1426. Frederick E. Bucheit, Appellant v.
Laudenberger, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania,
Western District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question.
No. 81-1609. Robert M. Helton, et al., Appellants v. City of
Burkburnett. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Texas, Second Su-
preme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substan-
tial federal question.
No. 81-1631. Robert Monroe Sheldon, Appellant v. Laura Lee Shel-
don. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate
District. The motion of appellee for damages and double costs is denied.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81-1641. Republican National Committee, et al., Appellants v.
Phillip Burton, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-1319. Carl White, Superintendent, Missouri Training Center
for Men, Petitioner v. Douglas W. Thompson. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of United States
v. Frady, 456 U.S. —(1982).

578
MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1982
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . West Virginia, Petitioner v. Secretary of Education,
United States Department of Eduction. The motion to direct the Clerk
to file the petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.
No. A-773. Owen W. Crumpacker, Applicant v. Indiana Supreme
Court Disciplinary Commission. The application for stay addressed to
Justice White and referred to the Court is denied.
No. A-861. Larry Mizell, Applicant v. Gary Welsh. The application
for stay addressed to Justice Rehnquist and referred to the Court is
denied.
No. 80-1690. American Medical Association, et al., Petitioners Fed-
eral Trade Commission. The motion of American Dental Association for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae in support of petition for rehearing
is denied. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this motion.
No. 81-31. California, et al., Appellants v. Grace Brethren Church,
et al.; and California, et al., Appellants v. Lutheran Church-Missouri
Synod, et al.;
No. 81-228. United States, et al., Appellants v. Grace Brethren
Church, et al.; and
No. 81-455. Grace Brethren Church, et al., Appellants v. United
States, et al. The motion of Grace Brethren Church, et al. for leave to
file a supplemental brief after argument is granted.
No. 81-55. New York, Petitioner v. Paul Ira Ferber. The motion of
American Booksellers Association, Inc., et al. for leave to participate in
oral argument as amici curiae and for divided argument is denied.
No. 81-1095. John Paul Morris, Warden, Petitioner v. Joseph D.
Slappy. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed further herein in
forma pauperis is granted. The motion for appointment of counsel is
granted and it is ordered that Michael B. Bassi, Esquire, of San Fran-
cisco, California, is appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in
this case.
No. 81–1222. United States, Petitioner v. Generix Drug Corporation,
et al. The motion of Generic Pharmaceutical Industry Association for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Medicine
in the Public Interest for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. The motion of The Proprietary Association for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Pharmaceutical Manu-
facturers Association for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted.

ORDER
It is ordered that the call of the calendar, except for special assign-
ments, be suspended for the term upon the conclusion of the arguments
in the cases listed for hearing this week.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, May 3, 1982, until Mon-
day, May 17, 1982.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, APRIL 28, 1982
595
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Before we open our regular proceedings this morning on this, the
last day of oral argument for the 1981 Term, we pause to note with sad-
ness, the death of our colleague former Justice Abe Fortas in his 72nd
year. Justice Fortas served on this Court from 1965 to 1969 after a rich
and unusually varied experience in government, in private practice and
a variety of activities relating to the law. He served as a legal adviser to
the United Nations Organization and the American delegation to that
Conference at San Francisco, as a visiting professor of law at the Yale
Law School and a periodic lecturer at other law schools. His career in
government at a very early age included service as General Counsel of
the Public Works Administration under President Roosevelt and as Un-
dersecretary of the Interior. After his return to private practice, he
served from 1970 until the time of his death as a member of the very
important Committee on Appellate Rules of the Judicial Conference of
the United States. He had appeared as counsel at this lecturn often,
and his final appearance in this Court was on March 22, 1982-barely
two weeks before his death."
"The record will show that the recess of the Court on this final day of
oral argument of the Term will be in memory of Justice Fortas, and in
the October Term coming, there will be the traditional memorial serv-
ice in this Chamber."

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 80-2162. Ramah Navajo School Board, Inc., et al., Appellants v.
Bureau of Revenue of New Mexico. Argued by Mr. Michael P. Gross
for the appellants, by Mr. Louis F. Claiborne for the United States as
amicus curiae, by special leave of Court, and by Mr. Jan Unna for the
appellees.

United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America. Argued by
Mr. Donald C. Robinson for the petitioner and by Mr. David S. Paull
for the respondent.

al. Argued by Mr. Robert S. Hammer for the appellant and by Mr.
Martin A. Schwartz for the appellees.
No. 81-750. Fidelity Federal Savings and Loan Association, et al.,
Appellants v. Reginald D. de la Cuesta, et al. Argued by Mr. Ernest
Leff for the appellants, by Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro for the FHLBB and
FHLMC as amicus curiae, by special leave of Court, and by Mr. Rob-
ert E. Boehmer for the appellees.
ORDERS
Ordered:
1. That the rules and forms governing proceedings in the United
States district courts under Section 2254 and Section 2255 of Title 28,
United States Code, be, and they hereby are, amended by in- cluding
therein an amendment to Rule 2(c) of the rules for Section 2254 cases,
an amendment to Rule 2(b) of the rules for Section 2255 proceedings,
and amendments to the model forms for use in applications under Sec-
tion 2254 and motions under Section 2255.
2. That the aforementioned amendments shall take effect August 1,
1982, and shall be applicable to all proceedings thereafter commenced
and, insofar as just and practicable, all proceedings then pending.

WEDNESDAY, APRIL 28, 1982
.
597
3. That the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to transmit
the aforementioned amendments to the Congress in accordance with
Section 2072 of Title 28 and Sections 3771 and 3772 of Title 18, United
States Code.
Ordered:
1. That the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure be, and they hereby
are, amended by including therein amendments to Rule 1, 5(b), 9(a),
9(a)(1), 9(b)(2), 9(c)(1), 9(c)(2), ll(c)(1), ll(c)(4), 11(c)(5), 20(b), 40(d)(1),
40(d)(2), 45(a), 54(a), 54(b) and 54(c).
2. That subdivision (d) of Rule 9 of the Federal Rules of Criminal
Procedure is hereby abrogated.
3. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Criminal
Procedure shall take effect on August 1, 1982, and shall govern all crim-
inal proceedings thereafter commenced and, insofar as just and practi-
cable, all proceedings then pending.
4. That the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Criminal Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Sections 3771
and 3772 of Title 18, United States Code.
Ordered:
1. That the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure be, and they hereby
are, amended by including therein amendments to Rule 4.
2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Civil Pro-
cedure shall take effect on August 1, 1982, and shall govern all civil pro-
ceedings thereafter commenced and, insofar as just and reasonable, all
proceedings then pending.
3. That the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Civil Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072 of
Title 28, United States Code.
Adjourned until Monday, May 3, 1982 at 10 o'clock.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Jus-

APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-1207. David Rusk, et al., Appellants v. Joseph Espinosa, et
al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Cir-
cuit. The judgment is affirmed. Justice Rehnquist and Justice O'Connor
would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 81-1259. Western Maryland Railway Company, Appellant v.
Herschel H. Rose, III, Tax Commissioner of the State of West Vir-
ginia; and
No. 81-1267. Union-Mechling Corporation, Appellant v. Herschell H.
Rose, III, Tax Commissioner of the State of West Virginia. Appeals
from the Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia. The appeals are
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice White and
Justice Powell would note probable jurisdiction and set the cases for
oral argument.
No. 81-1351. Steven Michael Smith, Appellant v. Florida. Appeal
from the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 81-1671. Alfred Y. K. Au, Appellant v. Hoyt F. Kelly, et al.,
Trustees, dba Financial Plaza of the Pacific. Appeal from the Interme-
diate Court of Appeals of Hawaii. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a pe-
tition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 81-1753. John Balash, Appellant v. New York City Employees'
Retirement System, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New
York. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the pa-
pers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 81-1681. Jacob Brothers, Inc., et al., Appellants v. Luis M.
DeLeon (Velazquez). Appeal from the Superior Court of Connecticut,
Appellate Session. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question.

600
MONDAY, MAY 3, 1982
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-2117. Local Union No. 84, International Brotherhood of Elec-
trical Workers, AFL-CIO, Petitioner v. United States, et al. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Pull-
man-Standard v. Swint 456 U.S. - (1982).
No. 81-310. Jack Bergman, Warden, Petitioner v. Arthur Jackson
Burton. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari
is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Rose v. Lundy 455 U.S. (1982). Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Marshall and Justice Black-
mun join.
No. 81-1029. International Association of Machinists and Aerospace
Workers, AFL-CIO, et al., Petitioners v. Joseph Terrell, Jr., et al. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Pullman-Standard v. Swint 456 U.S. — (1982).
No. 81-1666. Leon G. Grant, Petitioner v. Washington Public Em-
ployment Relations Commission, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of Washington. The petition for writ of certiorari
is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
Supreme Court of Washington for further consideration in light of
Larson v. Valente 456 U.S. (1982).

granted.

OPINIONS
No. 80-203. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., Petitioner
v. J. J. Curran and Jacquelyn L. Curran. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit;
No. 80-757. New York Mercantile Exchange, et al., Petitioners v.
Neil Leist, Philip Smith and Incomco;
No. 80-895. Clayton Brokerage Co. of St. Louis, Inc., Petitioner v.
Neil Leist, Philip Smith and Incomco; and
No. 80-936. Heinold Commodities, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Neil

MONDAY, MAY 3, 1982
613
Leist, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. Judgments affirmed. Opinion by Justice Ste-
vens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Powell with whom Chief Justice
Burger, Justice Rehnquist and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 81-89. Walter Zant, Warden, Petitioner v. Alpha Otis O'Daniel
Stephens. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit. Question to be certified to the Supreme Court
of Georgia pursuant to Georgia Code Ann. Sec. 24-4536: What are the
premises of state law that support the conclusion that the death sen-
tence in this case is not impaired by the invalidity of one of the statu-
tory aggravating circumstances found by the jury? Opinion per curiam.
Announced by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall
with whom Justice Brennan joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Powell.
No. 81-534. John O'Dell, et al., Petitioners v. Andrew Espinoza, etc.,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Colorado. Writ dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Opinion per curiam. Announced by Jus-
tice Brennan.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 17, 1982
617
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, and
Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79-6584. In the Matter of Sheryl Ann Trapp, etc., Appellant.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Missouri. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction.
No. 81–1738. First National Bank of Saint Paul, Appellant v. Minne-
sota, by Jim Lord, its Treasurer. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Minnesota. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 81-1614. Stanley Rosenberg, et al., Appellants v. Johns-Manville
Sales Corporation, et al.; and
No. 81–1615. Jeanne Steinhardt, as Executrix of James McKee, Jr.,
Appellant v. Johns-Manville Corporation, et al. Appeals from the Court
of Appeals of New York. The appeals are dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeals were taken as petitions
for writs of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Justice Brennan took no part
in the consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 81-1649. City of Parma, Ohio, et al., Appellants v. Record Revo-
lution No. 6, Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Sixth Circuit. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for
further consideration in light of Village of Hoffman Estates v. Flipside,
Hoffman Estates, Inc., 455 U.S. (1982). Justice Stevens took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 81-1700. Robert J. Gilliland, Appellant v. City of Palmdale; and
Frank M. Gilliland, Jr., et. al., Appellants v. County of Los Angeles.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81-6202. Naomi Addison, et al., Appellants v. City of Chester,
South Carolina. Appeal from the Supreme Court of South Carolina. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.

618
MONDAY, MAY 17, 1982
No. 81-6424. Francis Bacik, Appellant v. Pennsylvania. Appeal from
the Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81–1731. Adolph Schatzle, Appellant v. James C. Kirkpatrick, et
al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western Dis-
trict of Missouri. The judgment is affirmed: Justice Rehnquist, concur-
ring. Appellant in this case requests that we overrule Kirkpatrick v.
Preisler, 394 U.S. 526 (1969). But here the District Court did not invali-
date a reapportionment plan duly adopted by the state legislature; it
merely adopted a plan of its own when the legislature was unable to
reach agreement. This case, therefore, does not require that we ad-
dress appellant's suggestion respecting Kirkpatrick v. Preisler, supra.
No. 81-1752. H. Gordon Howard, Appellant v. Board of County Com-
missioners of the County of Weld, Colorado, et al. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of Colorado. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 81-1770. Laverne Orwoll, et al., Appellants v. Sharon LaComb,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Minnesota. The judgment is affirmed. Justice Stevens would note prob-
able jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument. Justice Blackmun
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-1542. John Rivers, et al., Petitioners v. Rosenthal & Com-
pany. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith v. Curran,
456 U.S.
-
(1982).
No. 81–1118. International Molders and Allied Workers Union, AFL-
CIO, Local 342, et al., Petitioners v. Joseph Terrell, Jr., et al. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Pull-
man-Standard v. Swint, 456 U.S. (1982).
No. 81-1750. Washington, Petitioner v. Glenn Ruphert Gibson. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for

MONDAY, MAY 17, 1982
619
the Ninth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Engle v. Isaac, 456 U.S. (1982) and United
States v. Frady, 456 U.S. — (1982).
No. 81-1800. White-Wilson Medical Clinic, Inc., Petitioner v. Delores
J. Robbins. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further
consideration in light of Pullman-Standard v. Swint, 456 U.S.
(1982).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. John W. Ritter, M.D., Petitioner v. Board of Commission-
ers of Adams County Public Hospital District No. 1. The motion to di-
rect the Clerk to file the petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.
No. A-916. In Re Paul M. Drefke. The application for stay addressed
to Justice Rehnquist and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-264. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joshua Eilberg. Disbar-
ment entered.
No. 81-523. Container Corporation of America, Appellant v. Fran-
chise Tax Board. The motion of National Association of Manufacturers
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Com-
mittee on State Taxation of the Council of State Chambers of Com-
merce for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion
of EMI, Limited, for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
The motion of Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, et al. for leave to
file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Justice Stevens took no part in
the consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 81-1717. American Bank and Trust Company, et al., Petitioners
v. Dallas County, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in
this case expressing the views of the United States. Justice O'Connor
took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. 81-1784. American Cyanamid Company, Petitioner v. Oil, Chem-
ical and Atomic Workers International Union, et al. The Solicitor Gen-
eral is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the
United States.

620
MONDAY, MAY 17, 1982
No. 81-1871. Meco Incorporated, Applicant v. Charles S. Sinnette,
Judge, Boyd Circuit Court, etc., et al. The application for stay ad-
dressed to Justice Stevens and referred to the Court is denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED OR POSTPONED
No. 81-969. Washington, et al., Appellants v. United States. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. In this
case probable jurisdiction is noted.
No. 81-1590. William F. Bolger, et al., Appellants v. Youngs Drug
Products Corp. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Columbia. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.
No. 81-1020. Exxon Corporation, et al., Appellants v. Ralph
Eagerton, Jr., Commissioner of Revenue of Alabama, et al.; and
No. 81-1268. Exchange Oil and Gas Corporation, et al., Appellants v.
Ralph P. Eagerton, Jr., Commissioner of Revenue of the State of Ala-
bama. Appeals from the Supreme Court of Alabama. In these cases
probable jurisdiction is noted. These cases are consolidated and a total
of one hour is allotted for oral argument.
No. 81–1756. Jonathan Lehr, Appellant v. Lorraine Robertson, et al.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. Further consideration
of the question of jurisdiction is postponed to the hearing of the case on
the merits.

Eicke. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of Louisi-
ana, Third Circuit, granted.

motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.

granted.
No. 81-1463. United States, Petitioner v. Kelvin Hasting, et al. The
motion of respondent Kevin Wendell Anderson for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. The motion of respondent Gable Gibson for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The motion of respond-
ent Gregory Lamont Williams for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. The motion of respondent Kelvin Hasting for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis is granted. The motion of respondent Napoleon
Stewart for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit granted.

No. 81-1618. Weyerhaeuser Company and Willamette Industries,
Inc., Petitioners v. Lyman Lamb Company, et al.; and
No. 81-1619. Georgia-Pacific Corporation, Petitioner v. Lyman Lamb

States for leave to file briefs as amicus curiae are granted. The motion.
of The Business Roundtable for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. The motion of National Association of Manufacturers for leave
to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Bowie-Sims-
Prange, Inc., et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae in No.
81-1618 is granted. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted. The cases are consoli-
dated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument. Justice
White and Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of these motions and these petitions.
No. 81-1810. Emilio Naranjo, et al., Petitioners v. Larry Corriz. The
petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit granted limited to questions 1 and 2 presented by
the petition.

Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.
No. 81-1746. Purex Corporation, Petitioner v. The Procter & Gamble
Company and The Clorox Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied. Jus-
tice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 81-1563. The Sacramento Bee, etc., Petitioner v. United States
District Court for the Eastern District of California. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
denied. Justice Brennan would grant certiorari.

632
MONDAY, MAY 17, 1982
No. 81-1665. Dale K. Dykema, etc., et al., Petitioners v. United
States and Henry Graner, etc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied. Justice
White would grant certiorari.
No. 81-1730. Frank A. Hall, et al., Petitioners v. Albert Blake, et al.
The motion of respondents Albert Blake, Ralph Hamm and Patrick
Rahilly for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the First
Circuit denied.
No. 81-1769. Federated Publications, Inc., Petitioner v. Byron L.
Swedberg, Judge, Superior Court of Whatcom County. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Washington denied. Justice
Brennan and Justice Marshall would grant certiorari.
No. 81-5379. Henry Perry Sireci, Petitioner v. Florida. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 81-5562. Fred Marion Gilreath, Jr., Petitioner v. Georgia. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia denied. Dis-
senting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 81-5784. Robert Ike Combs, Petitioner v. Florida. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 81-5848. Larry Gilbert and J. D. Gleaton, Petitioners v. South
Carolina. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South
Carolina denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice
Marshall.
No. 81-5944. Charles Dwight Messer, Petitioner v. Florida. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Dissent-
ing statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 81-6338. Keith Fair, Petitioner v. Walter D. Zant, Warden,
Georgia Diagnostic and Classification Center. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the Superior Court of Georgia, Butts County, denied. Dis-
senting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 81-6385. Ignacio Alberto Ortiz, Petitioner v. Arizona. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona denied. Dissent-
ing statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 81-6435. Carey Dean Moore, Petitioner v. Nebraska. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Nebraska denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.

MONDAY, MAY 17, 1982
633
No. 81-6437. Jimmy Lee Smith, Petitioner v. Florida. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 80-2092. SCM Corporation, Petitioner v. Xerox Corporation;
No. 81-363. James H. Karr, Petitioner v. Joanne D. Karr;
No. 81-417. Louie L. Wainwright, Secretary, Florida Department of
Corrections, Petitioner v. Antonio Perez;
No. 81-547. David Diaz, et ux., et al., Petitioners v. Ronald Beyer, et
ux.;
No. 81-1000. California State Board of Equalization, Appellant v.
United States;
No. 81-1343. Jean Rosenbaum, Petitioner v. Kurt Rosenbaum;
No. 81-1419. Eunice C. Madison, Petitioner v. Marion S. Barry, Jr.,
etc., et al.;
No. 81-1471. John R. Immer, Petitioner v. Puerto Rico Maritime
Shipping Authority, et al.;
No. 81–1542. Stanley C. Mazaleski, etc., Petitioner v. Richard S.
Schweiker, Secretary, Department of Health and Human Services, et
al.;
No. 81-5897. Lawrence Doby Wilson, Petitioner v. United States;
No. 81-6132. Steven Douglas Hamilton, Petitioner v. Richard Mays,
et al.; and
No. 81-6395. Violette Goldblatt, Petitioner v. Elaine & Martin Vogel,
et al. Petitions for rehearing denied.
No. 81-824. Edward Dennis Jacks, Jr., Petitioner v. Jack R.
Duckworth, Warden; and
No. 81-5418. Timothy Papp, Petitioner v. Arnold R. Jago, Superin-
tendent, London Correctional Institution. The motions for leave to file
petitions for rehearing are denied.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until Monday, May 24, 1982.

OPINIONS
No. 81-535. United States Department of State, et al., Petitioners v.
The Washington Post Company. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice Rehnquist. Justice O'Connor concurs in the judgment.
No. 80-986. North Haven Board of Education, et al., Petitioners v.
Terrel H. Bell, Secretary, Department of Education, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
Judgment affirmed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice Powell with whom
the Chief Justice and Justice Rehnquist join.

MONDAY, MAY 17, 1982
642
No. 80-1765. American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Inc., Peti-
tioner v. Hydrolevel Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Opinion by Chief Justice Burger concur-
ring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Powell with whom
Justice White and Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 80-6045. Rubin Kremer, Petitioner v. Chemical Construction.
Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
White. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice
Brennan and Justice Marshall join. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens.
No. 81-341. Joseph Greene, et al., Appellants v. Linnie Lindsey, et
al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice O'Connor with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Rehn-
quist join.
No. 80-2150. Donald Finnegan, et al., Petitioners v. Harold D. Leu,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Chief Justice Burger.
Concurring opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Brennan
joins.
No. 80-2205. Morgan M. Finley, Clerk of the Circuit Court of Cook
County, Illinois, Petitioner v. Toni Murray. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Writ of certio-
rari dismissed as improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam an-
nounced by Chief Justice Burger.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 24, 1982
647
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, and
Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-1785. Ernest A. Hunter, Appellant v. New York State De-
partment of Civil Service. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New
York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 81-1855. Red Owl Stores, Inc., Appellant v. Commissioner of
Agriculture. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81-1787. Donald J. Devine, Director, Office of Personnel Man-
agement, et al., Appellants v. Thomas P. Sullivan. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Northern District of Illinois with instructions to dis-
miss the cause as moot.
No. 81-1814. Lake Carriers' Association, et al., Appellants v. Frank
J. Kelley, Attorney General of Michigan, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan. The judg-
ment is affirmed.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-493. United States Department of Education, Petitioner v.
Seattle University. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The motion of American Civil Liberties
Union Women's Rights Project, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici
curiae is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
consideration in light of North Haven Board of Education v. Bell, 456
U.S. (1982).
-
No. 80-1023. Terrel H. Bell, Secretary of Education, et al., Petition-
ers v. Dougherty County School System, etc. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

648
MONDAY, MAY 24, 1982
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of North Haven Board of
Education v. Bell, 456 U.S.
-
(1982).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-950. Board of Trustees of the Internal Improvement Trust
Fund of Florida, Applicant v. American Cyanamid Company. The ap-
plication to recall and stay the mandate addressed to Justice Brennan
and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-258. In the Matter of Disbarment of Stanley Roy Root. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-259. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bernard J. Coven. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-273. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard P. Micun. It is
ordered that Richard P. Micun, of Evergreen Park, Illinois, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 81-827. Jefferson County Pharmaceutical Association, Inc., Peti-
tioner v. Abbott Laboratories, et al. The motion of respondent Board of
Trustees of the University of Alabama for divided argument and for ad-
ditional time for oral argument is denied. Justice O'Connor took no part
in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 81-1271. Falls City Industries, Inc., Petitioner v. Vanco Bever-
age, Inc. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in
oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
No. 81-1958. Arizona Electric Power Cooperative, Inc., Petitioner v.
Mid-Louisiana Gas Company, et al. The motion of petitioner to expedite
consideration of petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED OR POSTPONED
No. 81–185. Chris Simopoulos, Appellant v. Virginia. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Virginia. In this case probable jurisdiction is
noted.
No. 81-1574. Local 926, International Union of Operating Engineers,
AFL-CIO, et al., Appellants v. Robert C. Jones. Appeal from the
Court of Appeals of Georgia. Further consideration of the question of
jurisdiction is postponed to the hearing of the case on the merits.

Missouri, et al.; and

poration, et al. The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted limited to

OPINIONS
No. 80–1991. Oregon, Petitioner v. Bruce Alan Kennedy. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Oregon. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals of Oregon for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Justice Powell. Opinion by Justice
Brennan concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Marshall joins.
Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment with whom Jus-
tice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 80–1798. Woelke & Romero Framing, Inc., Petitioner v. Na-
tional Labor Relations Board, et al.;
No. 80-1808. Pacific Northwest Chapter of the Associated Builders &
Contractors, Inc., Petitioner v. National Labor Relations Board, et al.;
and
No. 81–91. Oregon-Columbia Chapter, The Associated General Con-
tractors of America, Inc., Petitioner v. National Labor Relations
Board, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part and vacated in
part. Cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Marshall.

MONDAY, MAY 24, 1982
661
No. 80-1735. Federal Bureau of Investigation, et al., Petitioners v.
Howard S. Abramson. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Brennan joins.
Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom Justice Marshall
joins.
No. 80-1714. Joseph S. Hopper, Commissioner, Alabama Depart-
ment of Corrections and James D. White, Warden, Petitioners v. John
Louis Evans, III. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Chief Justice Burger. Statement by
Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall concurring in part and dissenting
in part.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JUNE 1, 1982
667
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-837. City of Indianola, Mississippi, et al., Appellants v. Nel-
son Dotson, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Mississippi. The judgment is affirmed.
No. 81-1856. Sumter County School District, et al., Appellants v.
Judson Edge, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Middle District of Georgia. The judgment is affirmed.
No. 81–1529. Walter Bilofsky and Raymond L. Weisberg, Appellants
v. George Deukmejian, Attorney General of California, et al. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice
Brennan and Justice White would note probable jurisdiction and set the
case for oral argument.
No. 81–1829. Kraft, Inc., Appellant v. Florida Department of Citrus.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81-1862. Howard Williams, et ux., Appellants v. James L.
Smith, et ux. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Wood County.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers.
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-656. Consolidated Foods Corporation, Petitioner v. Trudy
Unger. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of Kremer v. Chemi-
cal Construction Corp., 456 U.S. (1982). Concurring opinion by
Justice Blackmun.

668
No.
TUESDAY, JUNE 1, 1982
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Hydaburg Cooperative Association, et al., Petitioners v.
United States. The motion of petitioners for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted.
No. A-968. Alan Ernest, etc., Applicant v. Richard S. Cohen, etc., et
al. The application for an injunction and/or writ of habeas corpus ad-
dressed to Justice O'Connor and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-263. In the Matter of Disbarment of John W. Kitchen. Disbar-
ment entered.
No. D-274. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard G. Kleindienst.
It is ordered that Richard G. Kleindienst, of Tucson, Arizona, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Justice Rehn-
quist and Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision
of this order.
No. 9 Original. United States of America, Plaintiff v. State of Loui-
siana, et al. The Final Report of the Special Master with respect to the
Louisiana Boundary case is received and ordered filed. The objections
to accountings previously filed are sustained to the extent recom-
mended in the Report of the Special Master. All accountings required
by the Court's Decree of June 22, 1981, have been made and, as supple-
mented by the ruling on the objections thereto, are now approved. The
account submitted by the Special Master is approved and the balance
owing to him shall be paid in equal shares by the United States and the
State of Louisiana. The Special Master is discharged in this case insofar
as the proceedings involve the controversy between the United States
and the State of Louisiana. Justice Marshall took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this order.
No. 73 Original. State of California, Plaintiff v. State of Nevada. The
Report of the Special Master is received and ordered filed. Final De-
cree entered.
No. 80 Original. State of Colorado, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico
and Jeff Bingaman, Attorney General of the State of New Mexico. The
motion of Kaiser Steel Corporation, et al. for leave to file a brief, as
amici curiae is granted. The Exceptions of New Mexico to the Report
of the Special Master are set for oral argument in due course.
No. 81-1120. United States, et al., Petitioners v. Richard W. Ry-
lander, Sr., as President of Rylander & Co. Realtors, Inc., et al. The
motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Jo-
seph F. Harbison, III, Esquire, of Sacramento, California, is appointed
to serve as counsel for respondent Richard W. Rylander, Sr. in this
case.

TUESDAY, JUNE 1, 1982
669
No. 81–1798. Larry V. Muko, Inc., Petitioner v. Southwestern Penn-
sylvania Building and Construction Trades Council, et al. The Solicitor
General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the
United States.
No. 81-5848. Larry Gilbert and J. D. Gleaton, Petitioners v. South
Carolina. The application to suspend the effect of the order denying cer-
tiorari presented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court
is denied. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall would grant the
application.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 81–1487. BankAmerica Corporation, et al., Petitioners v. United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 81-1581. Antone Olim, et al., Petitioners v. Delbert Kaahanui
Wakinekona. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.

No. 81-2044. Three J Farms, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Adams Ex-

Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Justice White and Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 81-1887. In Re Centre for the Independence of Judges and Law-
yers of the United States, Inc., Petitioner. Petition for writ of manda-
mus denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 81-1317. City of Parma, Ohio, Petitioner v. United States; and
No. 81-6271. James Harrison Barham, Petitioner v. United States.
Petitions for rehearing denied.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until Monday, June 7, 1982.

OPINIONS
No. 80-2182. Inwood Laboratories, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Ives
Laboratories, Inc.; and
No. 81–11. Darby Drug Co., Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Ives Labora-
tories, Inc. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice White
concurring in the result with whom Justice Marshall joins. Opinion by
Justice Rehnquist concurring in the result.
No. 80-2209. United States, Petitioner v. Albert Ross, Jr. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Co-
lumbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Concurring opinion by Justice
Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by
Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Jus-
tice Brennan joins.
No. 80–1437. Army and Air Force Exchange Service, Petitioner v.
Arthur Edward Sheehan. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Statement
by the Chief Justice concurring in the judgment.

TUESDAY, JUNE 1, 1982
682
No. 80-1749. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, et al., Appel-
lants v. Mississippi, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Southern District of Mississippi. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the District Court for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Opinion by
Justice Powell concurring in part and reversing in part. Opinion by Jus-
tice O'Connor concurring in part in the judgment and dissenting in part
with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 81-497. Summit Valley Industries, Inc., Petitioner v. Local 112,
United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 81-440. Insurance Corporation of Ireland, Ltd., et al., Petition-
ers v. Compagnie Des Bauxites de Guinee. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice White. Opinion by Justice Powell concurring
in the judgment.
Adjourned until Monday, June 7, 1982 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 7, 1982
683
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 81–1097. Kathy Sue Johnson, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Board of
Education of the City of Chicago, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The pe-
tition for a writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment of the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit is vacated and the case
is remanded with directions that the case be consolidated with the on-
going proceeding in the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Illinois in United States v. Board of Education of Chicago,
No. 80-C-5124, and for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Justice Brennan would grant
the petition and set the case for oral argument. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Rehnquist with whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice White took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81–1728. Raymond J. Donovan, Secretary of Labor, Appellant v.
San Antonio Metropolitan Transit Authority, et al.; and
No. 81-1735. Joe G. Garcia, Appellant v. San Antonio Metropolitan
Transit Authority, et al. Appeals from the United States District Court
for the Western District of Texas. The judgment is vacated and the
cases are remanded to the United States District Court for the Western
District of Texas for further consideration in light of United Transpor-
tation Union v. Long Island RR Co., 455 U.S. (1982). Justice
Brennan, Justice White and Justice Marshall would note probable juris-
diction and set the cases for oral argument.
_
No. 81-1878. Diane Lynn Williams, Appellant v. Cheetwood & Da-
vies, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Wood County.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.

684
MONDAY, JUNE 7, 1982
No. 81–6220. Roger Aldworth Beach, Appellant v. The Florida Bar.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 81–1882. Town of Chino Valley, et al., Appellants v. City of Pres-
cott. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Arizona. The motion of Ari-
zona for leave to intervene as a party appellee is granted. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice O'Connor
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion and this case.
No. 81-1974. Burlington Northern, Inc., Appellant v. Jack Henry,
etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Montana. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 81-6294. Vincent Robinson, Appellant v. Pennsylvania. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice Brennan
and Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set the case
for oral argument.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-1435. Army and Air Force Exchange Service, Petitioner v.
James O. Gorman. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Army & Air Force Exchange Service v.
Sheehan, 456 U.S. — (1982).
-
No. 81-1561. Michael P. Lane, Director, Illinois Department of Cor-
rections, Petitioner v. Melvin Lee Smith. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit for further consideration in light of Fletcher v. Weir,
455 U.S. (1982).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-992. Michael Escobar, Applicant v. Otis Bantim, Warden, et
al. The application for release addressed to Justice Brennan and re-
ferred to the Court is denied.

MONDAY, JUNE 7, 1982
685
No. D-257. In the Matter of Disbarment of Martin E. Gotkin. Disbar-
ment entered.
No. D-275. In the Matter of Disbarment of Rique Bobbitt. It is or-
dered that Rique Bobbitt, of Houston Texas, be suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-276. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael W. Hubbard. It
is ordered that Michael W. Hubbard, of Tyler Texas, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-277. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kenneth L. Boehm. It is
ordered that Kenneth L. Boehm, of Hyattsville Maryland, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 80 Original. State of Colorado, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico
and Jeff Bingaman, Attorney General of the State of New Mexico. The
motion of New Mexico, et al. for additional time for oral argument is
denied.
No. 81-349. Chicago Bridge & Iron Company, Appellant v. Caterpil-
lar Tractor Co., et al. The motion of appellees to schedule oral argu-
ment in tandem with No. 81-523, Container Corporation of America v.
Franchise Tax Board is denied. Justice Stevens took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion.
No. 81-485. Hillsboro National Bank, Petitioner v. Commissioner of
Internal Revenue; and
No. 81-930. United States, Petitioner v. Bliss Dairy, Inc. The motion
of Bliss Dairy, Inc. for divided argument is granted.
No. 81–1008. Burlington Northern, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. United
States, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for divided argument
is granted.
No. 81-1320. William Kolender, et al., Appellants v. Edward
Lawson. The motion of Wayne County Prosecutor for leave to partici-
pate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for additional time for argu-
ment is denied.
No. 81-1972. Frances E. Porcher, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Mary E.
Brown, etc., et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.

ferred to the Court is denied.

Circuit denied.

for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appel-

statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.

693
