ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Justice Stew-
art (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit for the period November 16, 1982 to No-
vember 18, 1982, and for such further time as may be required to com-
plete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec. 294(a), is ordered
entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec. 295.
ORDER
It is ordered that Christopher W. Vasil be, and he is hereby, ap-
pointed Deputy Clerk of this Court, effective June 1, 1982.
RECESS
The Court will take a recess from today until Monday, June 14, 1982.
OPINIONS
No. 81-5114. Delbert Lee Tibbs, Petitioner v. Florida. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 81-411. Jackson Transit Authority, et al., Petitioners v. Local
Division 1285, Amalgamated Transit Union, AFL-CIO-CLC. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the judgment of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Justice Powell with
whom Justice O'Connor joins.
No. 81-328. Jesus Rivera Rodriguez, et al., Appellants v. Popular
Democratic Party, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Puerto
Rico. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Chief Justice Burger.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1982
701
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice White, Justice Marshall, Jus-
tice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 88, Original. State of California, Plaintiff v. State of Texas, et
al. Motion for leave to file Bill of Complaint granted. The defendants
shall have sixty days to answer. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Powell with whom Justice Marshall, Justice Rehnquist, and
Justice Stevens join.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-1953. Starview Drive In Theatre, Inc., Appellant v. Cook
County, Illinois, et al. Appeal from the Appellate Court of Illinois,
First District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Justice Brennan would note probable jurisdiction and set the
case for oral argument.
No. 81-1964. Raymond B. Gorrell, Appellant v. Donald P. Fowler
and Jerry W. Fowler. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81-6382. Malcolm Joe Davis, Appellant v. Mississippi. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Mississippi. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Justice White
would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-804. Louisville and Jefferson County Transit Authority, etc.,
Petitioner v. Division 1447, Amalgamated Transit Union, AFL-CIO.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Jackson Transit Authority v. Local Division 1285 Amalgamated
Transit Union, 457 U.S. (1982).

702
MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1982
No. 81–908. United States, Petitioner v. Edward M. Spieler. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of United
States v. Ross, 456 U.S. (1982).
No. 81–953. United States, Petitioner v. Lawrence William Cleary,
Jr. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of United States v. Ross, 456 U.S.
(1982).
No. 81-1089. Maine, Petitioner v. Michael A. Patten. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Maine. The motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the Supreme Judicial Court of Maine for further
consideration in light of United States v. Ross, 456 U.S. (1982).
-
No. 81–1287. Alabama, Petitioner v. Freddie Lee Wright. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama.
The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of
Alabama for further consideration in light of Hopper v. Evans, 456 U.S.
(1982).
No. 81–1397. Alabama, Petitioner v. John Ronald Daniels. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama.
The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of
Alabama for further consideration in light of Hopper v. Evans, 456 U.S.
(1982).
No. 81-1514. Alabama, Petitioner v. Charles Bracewell. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama
for further consideration in light of Hopper v. Evans, 456 U.S.
(1982).
No. 81-1515. Alabama, Petitioner v. Walter Hill. On petition for writ
- ོ་་་་་

MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1982
703
of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama. The motion
of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama for
further consideration in light of Hopper v. Evans, 456 U.S. · - (1982).
-
No. 81–1662. Alabama, Petitioner v. Timothy Charles Davis. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama.
The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of
Alabama for further consideration in light of Hopper v. Evans, 456 U.S.
(1982).
No. 81-1809. Alabama, Petitioner v. Edward Horsley. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama
for further consideration in light of Hopper v. Evans, 456 U.S.
(1982).
No. 81-1513. Alabama, Petitioner v. Earl A. Bryars, Jr. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama for
further consideration in light of Hopper v. Evans, 456 U.S. — (1982).
No. 81-1600. Alabama, Petitioner v. Wayne Eugene Ritter. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama. The motion
of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Alabama for further con-
sideration in light of Hopper v. Evans, 456 U.S. — (1982).
No. 81-1995. Louie L. Wainwright, Secretary, Florida Department
of Corrections, Petitioner v. James Dupree Henry. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma paupe-
ris is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of
Engle v. Isaac, 456 U.S. (1982).

denied.

MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1982

siana, et al. The motion of Mississippi for relief from the final decree

this motion.

motion for entry of judgment by consent of plaintiff and defendant with

paragraph 7, is granted. Final decree entered.

v. Sue Gottfried, et al.; and

motion of respondent to dismiss writ of certiorari as improvidently
granted is denied. Further consideration of the memorandum of peti-
tioner suggesting a question of mootness and addressing related issues
is deferred to the hearing of the case on the merits.

motion of plaintiffs in the “Dalkon Shield” IUD Products Liability Case

England Legal Foundation for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. The motion of National Association of Independent Insurers,
et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 81-1852. Montana and Ramon Dore, Director, Montana Depart-
ment of Revenue, Petitioners v. Crow Tribe of Indians. The Solicitor
General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the
United States.

OPINIONS
No. 81-574. General Telephone Company of the Southwest, Peti-
tioner v. Mariano S. Falcon. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by
the Chief Justice concurring in part and dissenting in part.
No. 81-395. United Steelworkers of America, AFL-CIO-CLC, Peti-
tioner v. Edward Sadlowski, Jr., et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom
the Chief Justice, Justice Brennan and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 81-770. Barbara Blum, etc., Appellant v. Jeanne Bacon, etc., et
al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 80-1556. Kenneth Cory, Controller of the State of California, et
al., Petitioners v. Mark White, Attorney General of the State of
Texas, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Opinion by Justice.
Brennan concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Powell with whom Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens join.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JUNE 15, 1982
727
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 81-451. Ralph Hathorn, et al., Petitioners v. Mrs. Bobby Lov-
orn, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Missis-
sippi for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Justice Powell concurs in the judg-
ment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist.
No. 80-1538. James Plyler, Superintendent of the Tyler Independent
School District and its Board of Trustees, et al., Appellants v. J. and R.
Doe, et al.; and
No. 80-1934. Texas, et al., Appellants v. Certain Named and Un-
named Undocumented Alien Children, et al. Appeals from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgments affirmed.
Opinion by Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion by Justice Marshall.
Concurring opinion by Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Justice
Powell. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice with whom Justice
White, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 80-2070. Sumitomo Shoji America, Inc., Petitioner v. Lisa M.
Avagliano; and
No. 81-24. Lisa M. Avagliano, et al., Petitioners v. Sumitoma Shoji
America, Inc. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Chief Justice Burger.
No. 80-2204. Victor P. Diedrich, et ux., Petitioners v. Commissioner
of Internal Revenue; and United Missouri Bank of Kansas City, N.A.,
etc., Petitioner v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judg-
ments affirmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Rehnquist.
☑
Adjourned until Friday, June 18, 1982 at 10 o'clock.

1

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, JUNE 17, 1982
729
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Stevens, and
Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-1086. Jan Alf Assarsson, Applicant v. United States. The ap-
plication for stay of extradition and bail presented to Justice Stevens,
and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Justice Rehnquist took no
part in the consideration or decision of this application.



(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, JUNE 18, 1982
731
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Stevens, and
Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 81-31. California, et al., Appellants v. Grace Brethren Church,
et al.; and California, et al., Appellants v. Lutheran Church-Missouri
Synod, et al.;
No. 81–228. United States, et al., Appellants v. Grace Brethren
Church, et al.; and
No. 81-455. Grace Brethren Church, et al., Appellants v. United
States, et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the
Central District of California. Judgment vacated and cases remanded to
the District Court for further proceedings in conformity with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Stevens with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
No. 80-2195. United States, Petitioner v. Learley Reed Goodwin. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in
the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Jus-
tice Marshall joins.
No. 80-419. Arizona, Petitioner v. Maricopa County Medical Society,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Pow-
ell with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Rehnquist join. Justice
Blackmun and Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of this case.
No. 80–1417. Mark J. Mills, et al., Petitioners v. Rubie Rogers, et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the First
Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Powell.

732
FRIDAY, JUNE 18, 1982
No. 80–1429. Duane Youngberg, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Nicholas
Romeo, an Incompetent by his Mother and Next Friend, Paula Romeo.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Powell. Concurring opinion by Justice Black-
mun with whom Justice Brennan and Justice O'Connor join. Opinion by
the Chief Justice concurring in the judgment.
No. 89, Original. State of California, ex rel. State Lands Commis-
sion, Plaintiff v. United States. On cross motions for judgment. Califor-
nia's motion for summary judgment is denied, and the United States'
motion for judgment on the pleadings is granted. The parties, or either
of them, may, before September 27, 1982, submit a proposed decree to
carry this opinion into effect, failing which the Court will prepare and
enter an appropriate decree at the next Term of Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice White. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist concurring in the judgment
with whom Justice O'Connor joins.
Х
Adjourned until Monday, June 21, 1982 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 21, 1982
733
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Stevens, and
Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 81-1444. Johann Schmidt and Leland Pollard, etc., Petitioners v.
Oakland Unified School District, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81–1589. Hugh S. Hunt, Appellant v. Jerry L. Collins. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a properly presented federal question.
No. 81-1999. The Seymour National Bank, etc., et al., Appellants v.
Indiana. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Indiana. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81–1496. Michael E. Spiess, et al., Petitioners v. C. Itoh & Com-
pany (America), Inc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Sumitomo Shoji America, Inc. v. Avagliano,
457 U.S. (1982).
No. 81-1736. United States, Petitioner v. William Harris Sharpe and
Donald Davis Savage. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further
consideration in light of United States v. Ross, 456 U.S. (1982).
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Brennan and
Justice Marshall join.

734
MONDAY, JUNE 21, 1982
No. 81-1761. Eckerd Drugs, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Shirley
Brown, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The petition for writ of certio-
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further
consideration in light of General Telephone Co. of the Southwest v. Fal-
con, 457 U.S.
(1982).
-
No. 81–1849. United States, Petitioner v. James Edward Currie. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of United States v. Goodwin, 457 U.S.
-
(1982).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No.
-
Donald T. Regan, Secretary of the Treasury, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Taxation with Representation of Washington. The motion of
Disabled American Veterans and Paralyzed Veterans of American for
leave to intervene as party appellants is denied. The motion of Ameri-
can Legion for leave to intervene as a party appellee is denied. The mo-
tion of Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States for leave to inter-
vene is denied. Justice Brennan, Justice Blackmun and Justice
O'Connor would defer further consideration of these motions to the
docketing and consideration of the jurisdictional statement.
No. A-1054. Florida Businessmen for Free Enterprise, et al., Appli-
cants v. City of Hollywood, et al. The application for stay addressed to
Justice Stevens and referred to the Court is denied. Justice Rehnquist
and Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this
application.
No. A-1064. Howell & Howell, Inc., et al., Applicants v. Local Union
No. 118, International Brotherhood of Painters and Allied Trades. The
application for an injunction pending appeal addressed to Justice Ste-
vens and referred to the Court is denied. Justice Rehnquist took no
part in the consideration or decision of this application.
No. A-1084. Owen H. Brooks, etc., Applicant v. William F. Winter,
Governor of Mississippi, et al. The application for stay presented to
Justice White and by-him referred to the Court is denied. Justice Rehn-
quist took no part in the consideration or decision of this application.

MONDAY, JUNE 21, 1982
735
No. D-270. In the Matter of Andrew Bruce Moritz. Andrew Bruce
Moritz, of San Diego, California, having requested to resign as a mem-
ber of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from
the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court.
The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on May 3, 1982, is hereby
discharged.
No. 80-1190. Pullman-Standard, A Division of Pullman, Incorpo-
rated, Petitioner v. Louis Swint and Willie Johnson, etc.; and
No. 80-1193. United Steelworkers of America, AFL-CIO, et al., Pe-
titioners v. Louis Swint and Willie James Johnson. The motion of re-
spondents Louis Swint and Willie James Johnson for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis, nunc pro tunc, is denied.
No. 80-2128. Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority, Peti-
tioner v. William David Hensley. The motion of respondent for approval
of attorney's fees is denied without prejudice to applying for the relief
in the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Cir-
cuit. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of
this motion.
No. 81–1044. United States Postal Service Board of Governors, Peti-
tioner v. Louis H. Aikens. The motion of American Federation of Labor
and Congress of Industrial Organizations for leave to file a brief as ami-
cus curiae is granted.
No. 81-1489. Xerox Corporation, Appellant v. County of Harris,
Texas and City of Houston, Texas. The motion of appellees for divided
argument and for additional time for oral argument is denied.

CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 81-857. Oralia Martinez, as Next Friend of Roberto Morales, Pe-
titioner v. M. L. Brockette, etc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted.
No. 81–1938. United States, Petitioner v. James E. Baggot. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sev-
enth Circuit granted.
No. 81-1966. Belknap, Inc., Petitioner v. Duwaine E. Hale, et al. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky granted.
No. 81-1802. United States, Petitioner v. Leroy Carlton Knotts. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit granted.
No. 81–1983. Richard S. Schweiker, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, Petitioner v. Carmen Campbell. The motion of respondent for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
granted.
No. 81-1945. Pacific Gas and Electric Company, et al., Petitioners v.
State Energy Resources Conservation & Development Commission, et
al. The petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit is granted limited to the following ques-
tions: Whether petitioners' challenges to the provisions in the 1976
amendments to California's Warren-Alquist Act, Cal. Pub. Res. Code
Sections 25524.1(b) and 25524.2 (West 1977), which condition the con-
struction of nuclear plants on findings by the State Energy Resources.
Conservation and Development Commission that adequate storage fa-
cilities and means of disposal are available for high-level nuclear waste,
are ripe for judicial review, and whether Sections 25524.1(b) and
25524.2 are preempted by the Atomic Energy Act of 1954, 42 U.S.C.
Section 2011, et seq.
No. 81-2101. Pennhurst State School and Hospital, et al., Petitioners
v. Terri Lee Halderman, et al. The motion of respondents Terri Lee
Halderman, et al. for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit granted.

No. 81-213. Richard S. Schweiker, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, Appellant v. George Hogan, et al. Appeal from United States
District Court for the District of Massachusetts. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the District Court for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 80-1608. United States, Petitioner v. Raymond Eugene John-
son. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
Concurring opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice
White with whom the Chief Justice, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice
O'Connor join.
No. 80-1874. Georgia Patsy, Petitioner v. Board of Regents of the
State of Florida, etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Concur-
ring opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom Justice Rehnquist joins.
Concurring opinion by Justice White in all but Part III-B of the opinion
of the Court. Dissenting opinion by Justice Powell with whom the Chief
Justice joins in Part II.
No. 81-225. Blue Shield of Virginia, et al., Petitioners v. Carol
*McCready. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Bren-
nan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom the Chief
Justice and Justice O'Connor join. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens.
No. 80-2147. Connecticut, et al., Petitioners v. Winnie Teal, et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit. Judgment of the Court of Appeals is affirmed and case re-
manded to the United States District Court for the District of Connecti-
cut for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Powell with
whom the Chief Justice, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 81-460. Middlesex County Ethics Committee, etc., Petitioner v.
Garden State Bar Association, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and

MONDAY, JUNE 21, 1982
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Chief Justice Bur-
ger. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in the judgment. Opinion
by Justice Marshall concurring in the judgment with whom Justice
Brennan, Justice Blackmun, and Justice Stevens join.

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 23, 1982
753
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Stevens, and
Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 80-2134. Foremost Insurance Company, et al., Petitioners v.
Pansy F. Richardson, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Justice Powell with whom the
Chief Justice, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 81-5152. Omar Taylor, Petitioner v. Alabama. On writ of certio-
rari to the Supreme Court of Alabama. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Dissenting
opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom the Chief Justice, Justice Pow-
ell, and Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 80-1188. James Edgar, Appellant v. Mite Corporation and Mite
Holdings, Inc. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Justice White delivered an opin-
ion, Parts I, II, and V-B of which are the opinion of the Court, with
whom the Chief Justice, Justice White, Justice Blackmun, except for
Part V-B, Justice Powell, except for Part II, Justice Stevens and Jus-
tice O'Connor Join. Opinion by Justice Powell concurring in part. Opin-
ion by Justice Stevens concurring in part and concurring in the judg-
ment. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in part. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan joins. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Rehnquist.
No. 81-611. Globe Newspaper Company, Appellant v. Superior
Court for the County of Norfolk. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial
Court of Massachusetts. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Supreme Judicial Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Opinion by Jus-
tice O'Connor concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by the
Chief Justice with whom Justice Rehnquist joins. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Stevens.
Х
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

755
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Stevens, and
Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 79-1738. Richard Nixon, Petitioner v. A. Ernest Fitzgerald. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Powell. Concurring opinion by Chief
Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom Justice
Brennan, Justice Marshall, and Justice Blackmun join. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Mar-
shall join.
No. 80-945. Bryce N. Harlow and Alexander P. Butterfield, Petition-
ers v. A. Ernest Fitzgerald. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Powell. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in the opinion of the
Court with whom Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join. Concur-
ring statement by Justice Brennan, Justice White, Justice Marshall,
and Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Dis-
senting opinion by the Chief Justice.
No. 80-1045. Jacksonville Bulk Terminals, Inc., et al., Petitioners v.
International Longshoremen's Association, et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Opinion by Justice O'Connor
concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice
with whom Justice Powell joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Powell.
Dissenting statement by Justice Stevens.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

FRIDAY, JUNE 25, 1982
757
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 80-1290. William P. Clements, Jr., Governor of the State of
Texas, et al., Appellants v. John L. Fashing, et al. Appeal from the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Justice Rehnquist de-
livered the opinion of the Court with respect to Parts I, II, and V, and
delivered an opinion with respect to Parts III and IV, in which the
Chief Justice, Justice Powell, and Justice O'Connor join. Opinion by
Justice Stevens concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and
Justice Blackmun join, and with whom Justice White joins as to Part I.
No. 80–1952. Barbara Blum, Commissioner of the New York State
Department of Social Services, et al., Petitioners v. William Yaretsky,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Justice White concur-
ring in the judgment in this case and in No. 80-2102, Rendell-Baker v.
Kohn, post. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice
Marshall joins.
No. 80-1730. Giles M. Lugar, Petitioner v. Edmondson Oil Company,
Inc. and Ronald L. Barbour. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed in part and
affirmed in part and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice White. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Powell with whom Justice Rehnquist and Justice O'Con-
nor join.
No. 80-2043. Board of Education, Island Trees Union Free School
District No. 26, et al., Petitioners v. Steven A. Pico, by his next friend,
Frances Pico, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed and judgment shall

758
FRIDAY, JUNE 25, 1982
issue forthwith. Justice Brennan announced the judgment of the Court,
and delivered an opinion in which Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens
join, and in which Justice Blackmun joins except for Part II-A-(1).
Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in part and concurring in the
judgment. Opinion by Justice White concurring in the judgment. Dis-
senting opinion by the Chief Justice with whom Justice Powell, Justice
Rehnquist, and Justice O'Connor join. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Powell. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom the Chief
Justice and Justice Powell join. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor.
No. 80-2102. Sheila Rendell-Baker, et al., Petitioners v. Sandra
Kohn, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the First Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Chief Justice Bur-
ger. Opinion by Justice White concurring in the judgment in this case
and in No. 80-1952, Blum v. Yaretsky, ante. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan joins.

MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1982
759
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 81-593. Michigan, Petitioner v. Lamont Charles Thomas. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to Court of Appeals for further proceedings not inconsis-
tent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Justice Bren-
nan and Justice Marshall would grant the petition for a writ of certio-
rari and set the case for oral argument.
No. 81-1144. United States, Petitioner v. Hollywood Motor Car
Company, Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun
with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-634. Sharon Steel Corporation and Summit Systems, Inc.,
Appellants v. Insurance Commissioner of New Hampshire and Nashua
Corporation. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Hampshire. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of
New Hampshire for further consideration in light of Edgar v. Mite
Corp., 457 U.S. (1982).
- -
No. 81-2062. New York Shipping Association, Inc., et al., Appellants
v. Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor. Appeal from the
Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.

760
MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1982
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-1699. Dr. Ingre Rudolph Plante, Commissioner of Institu-
tions and Agencies, et al., Petitioners v. Allen Bodine Scott, etc. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit. The motion of American Psychiatric Association for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further
consideration in light of Youngberg v. Romeo, 457 U.S. (1982).
-
No. 80-6397. Richard Graham, Petitioner v. New York. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New
York, Third Judicial Department. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Ap-
pellate Division, Supreme Court of New York, Third Judicial Depart-
ment, for further consideration in light of United States v. Johnson, 457
U.S. — (1982).
-
No. 80-6758. Brian Miller, Petitioner v. New York. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New
York, Fourth Judicial Department. The motion of petitioner for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Ap-
pellate Division, Supreme Court of New York, Fourth Judicial Depart-
ment, for further consideration in light of United States v. Johnson, 457
U.S. _ (1982).
-
No. 81-261. Lawrence R. Meachum and Fred Butterworth, Petition-
ers v. Norman L. Longval. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. The motion of re-
spondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the First
Circuit for further consideration in light of United States v. Goodwin,
457 U.S. (1982).
-
No. 81-835. Iron Arrow Honor Society, etc., Petitioner v. Richard S.
Schweiker, Secretary, Department of Health and Human Services, et
al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted.
The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light
of North Haven Board of Education v. Bell, 456 U.S. (1982). Jus-
tice Brennan, Justice White, Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun
dissent.

MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1982
761
No. 81–1134. John Ashcroft, Attorney General of Missouri, Peti-
tioner v. National Organization for Women, Inc. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of Nixon v. Fitzgerald,
457 U.S. -,
(1982) (Slip opinion pages 9-11).
No. 81-1580. Nick Sanborn and John D. Barkeloo, Petitioners v.
Dennis M. Wolfel. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certio-
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Harlow v. Fitzgerald, 457 U.S. -(1982). See
Butz v. Economou, 438 U.S. 478, 504 (1978) (deeming it "untenable to
draw a distinction for purposes of immunity law between suits brought
against state officials under Sec. 1983 and suits brought directly under
the Constitution against federal officials”).
-
No. 81-5871. Kenneth Ford, Petitioner v. Kentucky. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky. The motion of pe-
titioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ
of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Kentucky for further consideration in
light of United States v. Johnson, 457 U.S. ——— (1982).
No. 81-6225. Charles Gilmore, Petitioner v. Pennsylvania. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, East-
ern District. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of
Pennsylvania, Eastern District, for further consideration in light of
United States v. Johnson, 457 U.S. (1982).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 72, Original. State of South Dakota, Plaintiff v. State of Ne-
braska. The Report of the Special Master is received and ordered filed.
Decree entered pursuant to parties' Stipulations and Findings. Each
party shall bear its own costs.

Corporation, Applicants v. Commodity Futures Trading Commission,
et al. The application for stay addressed to Justice Rehnquist and re-
ferred to the Court is denied. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this application.

MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1982
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
771
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Justice Stew-
art (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for the period September 13, 1982 to Sep-
tember 17, 1982, and for such further time as may be required to com-
plete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec. 294(a), is ordered
entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec. 295.

MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1982
776
OPINIONS
No. 81-300. Ford Motor Company, Petitioner v. Equal Employment
Opportunity Commission. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Brennan and Justice
Marshall join.
No. 80-1002. Board of Education of the Hendrick Hudson Central
School District, Westchester County, et al., Petitioners v. Amy Row-
ley, by her Parents and Natural Guardians, Clifford and Nancy Row-
ley, etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Justice Blackmun con-
curring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with
whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
No. 81-750. Fidelity Federal Savings and Loan Association, et al.,
Appellants v. Reginald D. de la Cuesta, et al. Appeal from the Court of
Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate District. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeal for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Black-
mun. Concurring opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Rehnquist with whom Justice Stevens joins. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 80-2178. John S. Toll, President, University of Maryland, et al.,
Petitioners v. Juan Carlos Moreno, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion by Justice
Blackmun. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in part and dissent-
ing in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom the
Chief Justice joins.
No. 81-389. Union Labor Life Insurance Company, Petitioner v. A.
Alexander Pireno; and
No. 81–390. New York State Chiropractic Association, Petitioner v.
A. Alexander Pireno. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Jus-
tice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom the
Chief Justice and Justice O'Connor join.

MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1982
777
No. 81-150. Northern Pipeline Construction Co., Appellant v. Mara-
thon Pipe Line Company and United States; and
No. 81–546. United States, Appellant v. Marathon Pipe Line Co., et
al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the District of
Minnesota. Judgment affirmed. However, the judgment of this Court is
stayed until October 4, 1982. This limited stay will afford Congress an
opportunity to reconstitute the bankruptcy courts or to adopt other
valid means of adjudication, without impairing the interim administra-
tion of the bankruptcy laws. Justice Brennan announced the judgment
of the Court and delivered an opinion in which Justice Marshall, Justice
Blackmun, and Justice Stevens join. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist con-
curring in the judgment with whom Justice O'Connor joins. Dissenting
opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with
whom the Chief Justice and Justice Powell join.
ADMISSIONS TO THE BAR ON ORAL MOTIONS
Applicant
City and State
Ruth Van Roekel McGregor Phoenix, AZ
Movant
John J. O'Connor,
III
Darwin E. Johnson
Kansas City, MO
Jan Horbaly
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

rized to say that after the announcement of the five opinions to be

OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 81-1577. Board of Education of Rogers, Arkansas, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Pete McCluskey, by his next friend, Sally McCluskey. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice
Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-922. Pan American Saving & Loan Association, et al., Appel-
lants v. Stanley E. Panko and George L. Sinclair. Appeal from the
Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the Court of Appeal of California,
First Appellate District, for further consideration in light of Fidelity
Federal Savings & Loan Association v. de la Cuesta, 458 U.S.
(1982).
No. 81–992. Glendale Federal Savings and Loan Association, et al.,
Appellants v. Gary G. Hehir, et ux.; and
No. 81-993. California Federal Savings and Loan Association, Appel-
lant v. Nini Myrna Tan, et al.; and California Federal Savings and Loan
Association, Appellant v. William Romagnoli, et al. Appeals from the
Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate District. The judgment
is vacated and the cases are remanded to the Court of Appeal of Califor-
nia, Fourth Appellate District, for further consideration in light of
Fidelity Federal Savings & Loan Association v. de la Cuesta, 458 U.S.
(1982).
No. 81-1139. Glendale Federal Savings and Loan Association, et al.,
Appellants v. Dean L. Gross and Pedro Enriquez. Appeal from the
Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate District. The judgment

786
MONDAY, JULY 2, 1982
is vacated and the case is remanded to the Court of Appeal of Califor-
nia, Fourth Appellate District, for further consideration in light of Fi-
delity Federal Savings & Loan Association v. de la Cuesta, 458 U.S.
(1982).
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 80-1888. Dixie Herlong Chastain, Circuit Judge, etc., et al., Pe-
titioners v. Hilary Davis, etc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Lehman v. Lycoming County Chil-
dren's Services, 458 U.S. (1982).
-
No. 81-471. United States, Petitioner v. Jose Enrique Marquez-
Amaya. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari
is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of United States v. Valenzuela-Bernal, 458 U.S.
(1982).
No. 81-596. Springdale School District No. 50 of Washington County,
Petitioner v. Sherry Grace, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Board of Education of Hendrick
Hudson Central School District v. Rowley, 458 U.S. (1982).
No. 81-774. George C. Moore, Petitioner v. Black Panther Party, et
al.; and
No. 81-1511. William French Smith, Attorney General of the United
States, et al., Petitioners v. The Black Panther Party, et al. On peti-
tions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the District of Columbia Circuit. The petitions for writs of certiorari are
granted. The judgment is vacated and the cases are remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit
with directions that it instruct the United States District Court for the
District of Columbia to dismiss the complaint with prejudice. Justice
Marshall would deny the petitions for writs of certiorari. Justice Powell
and Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of
these cases.

787

to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Summit Valley Industries v. Local 112, United
Brotherhood of Carpenters, 456 U.S. (1982).

(1982).
ORDERS IN Pending CaSES
No. 88, Original. State of California, Plaintiff v. State of Texas, et al.
The motion for issuance of a restraining order is denied without preju-
dice. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of
this motion.
No. 92, Original. State of Arkansas, Plaintiff v. State of Mississippi.
It is ordered that Justice Paul C. Reardon (Retired) of Boston, Massa-
chusetts, is appointed Special Master in this case with authority to fix
the time and conditions for the filing of additional pleadings and to di-
rect subsequent proceedings, and with authority to summon witnesses,
issue subpoenas, and take such evidence as may be introduced and such
as he may deem necessary to call for. The Special Master is directed to
submit such reports as he may deem appropriate. The compensation of
the Special Master, the allowances to him, the compensation paid to his
technical, stenographic, clerical and legal assistants, the cost of printing
his report, and all other proper expenses shall be charged against and
be borne by the parties in such proportion as the Court may hereafter
direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master in this case
becomes vacant during a recess of the Court, the Chief Justice shall
have authority to make a new designation which shall have the same
effect as if originally made by the Court herein.
No. 80–1832. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Appellant v.
Jagdish Rai Chadha, et al.;
No. 80-2170. United States House of Representatives, Petitioner v.
Immigration and Naturalization Service, et al.; and

MONDAY, JULY 2, 1982

Naturalization Service, et al. These cases are restored to the calendar
for reargument. Justice Brennan and Justice Blackmun dissent.

rections, Petitioner v. Charles Edwin Bullard. The motion for appoint-
ment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Kenneth E. Houp, Jr.,
Esquire, of Austin, Texas, is appointed to serve as counsel for the re-
spondent in this case. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion.

and Justice Rehnquist join.

MONDAY, JULY 2, 1982
791
Justice White said:
"I am authorized to announce that all cases submitted to the Court
for decision and all other matters before the Court which were ready
for disposition, have been acted upon by the Court. Accordingly, it is
ordered that those cases remaining on the docket, but not ready for
consideration, are hereby continued to the session of the Court begin-
ning October 4 next.
The Court will be in recess from today until the first Monday in Octo-
ber, 1982, at which time the October 1981 Term of the Court will be
adjourned.
The October 1982 Term of the Court will begin as provided by statute
on the first Monday in October."

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, AUGUST 10, 1982
795
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, and
Justice Stevens.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-147. James P. Mitchell, Warden and Gerald L. Baliles, Attor-
ney General of Virginia, Applicants v. J. Gray Lawrence, Jr., individ-
ually and next friend acting on behalf of Frank Coppola. This matter
came on before the Chief Justice as Circuit Justice for the Fourth Cir-
cuit on the application of James P. Mitchell, Warden and Gerald L.
Baliles, Attorney General of Virginia, and was referred by him to the
Court. There being only four members of the Court available in Wash-
ington, a conference call was arranged to include those outside Wash-
ington except Justice O'Connor who was outside the United States.
After consideration of the matters presented by the application of the
petitioners, the application is granted and the stay entered by Circuit
Judge John D. Butzner, Jr., of the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit is hereby vacated. Justice Brennan and Justice Mar-
shall would deny the application. Justice Stevens would call for a re-
sponse from J. Gray Lawrence, Jr., the respondent above named. Jus-
tice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this
application.



(JOURNAL)

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-169. Larry Kallenberger, Applicant v. Mary Estill Buchanan,
Secretary of State, Colorado. The application for an injunction ad-
dressed to Justice Brennan and referred to the Court is denied. Justice
Blackmun would grant the application. Justice Marshall would defer
consideration of the application pending the filing of a response by the
respondent. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this application.

No. D-285. In the Matter of Disbarment of George N. Gloeckner. It
is ordered that George N. Gloeckner, of Columbus, Ohio, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable.
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-286. In the Matter of Disbarment of Floyd Norman Nadler. It
is ordered that Floyd Norman Nadler, of Chicago, Illinois, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-287. In the Matter of Disbarment of Rodney S. Bonds. It is
ordered that Rodney S. Bonds, of Baltimore, Maryland, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

No. 80–1640. United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, et al.,
Petitioners v. Steven Sholly, et al.; and
No. 80-1656. Metropolitan Edison Company, et al., Petitioners v.
People Against Nuclear Energy, et al. The motion of respondents for
further deferral of oral argument is granted.
No. 81–185. Chris Simopoulos, Appellant v. Virginia. The motion of
National Organization for Women, et al., for leave to file a brief as
amici curiae is granted. The motion of Committee for Abortion Rights
and Against Sterilization Abuse, et al., for leave to file a brief as amici
curiae is granted. The motion of Certain Law Professors for leave to
file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 81-334. Associated General Contractors of California, Inc., Peti-
tioner v. California State Council of Carpenters and Carpenters 46
Northern Counties Conference Board, et al. The motion of American
Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations for leave
to file a supplemental brief as amicus curiae is granted.

802
THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 9, 1982
No. 81-430. Illinois, Petitioner v. Lance Gates, et ux. The motion of
respondents for divided argument is denied.
No. 81-523. Container Corporation of America, Appellant v. Fran-
chise Tax Board. The motion of Union of Industries of the European
Community for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The
motion of Committee on State Taxation of the Council of State Cham-
bers of Commerce for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus
curiae and for additional time for argument is denied. The motion of
Committee on Unitary Tax for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of
these motions.
No. 81-680. Herman & MacLean, Petitioner v. Ralph E. Huddleston,
et al.; and
No. 81-1076. Ralph E. Huddleston, et al., Petitioners v. Herman &
MacLean, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to partici-
pate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is
granted.
No. 81-773. North Dakota, Appellant v. United States. The motion
of National Wildlife Federation, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici
curiae is granted.
No. 81-897. Director, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs,
United States Department of Labor, Petitioner v. Perini North River
Associates, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for divided argu-
ment is denied. The motion of the Solicitor General to permit Richard
G. Wilkins, Esquire, to present oral argument pro hac vice is granted.
No. 81-1003. Kevin H. White, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Massachu-
setts Council of Construction Employers, Inc., et al. The motion of
American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organiza-
tions, et al., for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 81-1251. Harry Connick, Individually and in his capacity as Dis-
trict Attorney, etc., Petitioner v. Sheila Myers. The motion of National
Education Association, et al., for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is
granted. The motion of American Civil Liberties Union, et al., for leave
to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 81-1489. Xerox Corporation, Appellant v. County of Harris,
Texas and City of Houston, Texas. The motion of International Associa-
tion of Assessing Officers for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted.
No. 81–1493. The Gillette Company, Petitioner v. Steven Miner. The

THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 9, 1982
803
motion of Public Citizen for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. The motion of Consumer Coalition for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted.
No. 81-1506. Federal Election Commission, et al., Petitioners v. Na-
tional Right to Work Committee, et al. The motion of American Fed-
eration of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizatons for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 81-1578. Werner H. Kramarsky, etc., et al., Appellants v. Delta
Air Lines, Inc., et al.; Werner H. Kramarsky, etc., Appellant v. Bur-
roughs Corporation; and Werner H. Kramarsky, etc., et al., Appellants
v. Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. The motion of American Fed-
eration of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, et al., for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The motion of appellants
Werner H. Kramarsky, et al., for divided argument and for leave to file
separate brief and joint appendix is denied.
No. 81-1613. Memphis Bank & Trust Company, Appellant v. Riley
C. Garner, Shelby County Trustee, et al. The motion of Capital Pres-
ervation Fund, Inc., et al., for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is
granted. The motion of The Farm Credit Banks for leave to file a brief
as amici curiae is granted.
No. 81-1627. Larry Shepard, Petitioner v. National Labor Relations
Board, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for divided argument
and for additional time for oral argument is denied.
No. 82-78. California, Petitioner v. Donald Lee Shirley. The applica-
tion for stay of enforcement of the judgment of the Supreme Court of
California addressed to the Chief Justice and referred to the Court is
denied.
No. 82–157. Mark A. Smith, Petitioner v. Al Olson, Registrar of Vot-
ers, Orange County, California, et al. The application for an injunction
addressed Justice Brennan and referred to the Court is denied.
No. 82-274. Pennsylvania, et al., Petitioners v. Delaware Valley Citi-
zens' Council for Clean Air, et al. The application for stay addressed to
Justice Rehnquist and referred to the Court is denied.
